国务院关于推进资本市场改⾰开放和稳定发展的若⼲意⻅_宏观经济_中国政府⽹2025/9/12,10:38国务院关于推进资本市场改⾰开放和稳定发展的若⼲意见国发〔2004〕3号各省、⾃治区、直辖市⼈民政府，国务院各部委、各直属机构：《国务院关于进⼀步加强证券市场宏观管理的通知》（国发〔1992〕68号）下发以来，我国资本市场发展迅速，取得了举世瞩⽬经济体系的重要组成部分，为国有企业、⾦融市场改⾰和发展，优化资源配置，促进经济结构调整和经济发展，作出了重要贡献。为贯彻落实党的⼗六⼤和⼗六届三中全会精神，围绕全⾯建设⼩康社会的战略⽬标，积极推进资本市场改⾰开放和稳定发展，现提出如下意见.**一、充分认识大力发展资本市场的重要意义**⼤⼒发展资本市场是⼀项重要的战略任务，对我国实现本世纪头20年国民经济翻两番的战略⽬标具有重要意义。⼀是有利于完善社会主义市场经济体制，更⼤程度地发挥资本市场优化资源配置的功能，将社会资⾦有效转化为长期投资。⼆是有利于国有经济的结构调整和战略性改组，加快⾮国有经济发展。三是有利于提⾼直接融资⽐例，完善⾦融市场结构，提⾼⾦融市场效率，维护⾦融安全。我国资本市场是伴随着经济体制改⾰的进程逐步发展起来的。由于建⽴初期改⾰不配套和制度设计上的局限，资本市场还存在⼀些深层次问题和结构性⽭盾，制约了市场功能的有效发挥。这些问题是资本市场发展中遇到的问题，也只有在发展中逐步加以解决。党的⼗六https://www.gov.cn/zhengce/content/2008-03/28/content_2071.htmPage1of8国务院关于推进资本市场改⾰开放和稳定发展的若⼲意⻅_宏观经济_中国政府⽹2025/9/12,10:38⼤提出了全⾯建设⼩康社会的战略⽬标，⼗六届三中全会通过了《中共中央关于完善社会主义市场经济体制若⼲问题的决定》，对资本市场发展作出了部署，为我国资本市场改⾰开放和稳定发展指明了⽅向。要认清形势，抓住机遇，转变观念，⼤⼒发展资本市场，提⾼直接融资⽐例，创造和培育良好的投资环境，充分发挥资本市场在促进资本形成、优化资源配置、推动经济结构调整、完善公司治理结构等⽅⾯的作⽤，为国民经济持续快速协调健康发展和全⾯建设⼩康社会作出新的贡献。**二、推进资本市场改革开放和稳定发展的指导思想和任务**推进资本市场改⾰开放和稳定发展的指导思想是：以邓⼩平理论和“三个代表”重要思想为指导，全⾯落实党的⼗六⼤和⼗六届三中全会精神，遵循“公开、公平、公正”原则和“法制、监管、⾃律、规范”的⽅针，坚持服务于国民经济全局，实现与国民经济协调发展；坚持依法治市，保护投资者特别是社会公众投资者的合法权益；坚持资本市场改⾰的市场化取向，充分发挥市场机制的作⽤；坚持改⾰的⼒度、发展的速度与市场可承受程度的统⼀，处理好改⾰、发展、稳定的关系；坚持⽤发展的办法解决前进中的问题，处理好加快资本市场发展与防范市场风险的关系；坚持循序渐进，不断提⾼对外开放⽔平。推进资本市场改⾰开放和稳定发展的任务是：以扩⼤直接融资、完善现代市场体系、更⼤程度地发挥市场在资源配置中的基础性作⽤为⽬标，建设透明⾼效、结构合理、机制健全、功能完善、运⾏安全的资本市场。要围绕这⼀⽬标，建⽴有利于各类企业筹集资⾦、满⾜多种投资需求和富有效率的资本市场体系；完善以市场为主导的产品创新机制，形成价格发现和风险管理并举、股票融资与债券融资相协调的资本市场产品结构；培育诚实守信、运作规范、治理机制健全的https://www.gov.cn/zhengce/content/2008-03/28/content_2071.htmPage2of8国务院关于推进资本市场改⾰开放和稳定发展的若⼲意⻅_宏观经济_中国政府⽹2025/9/12,10:38上市公司和市场中介群体，强化市场主体约束和优胜劣汰机制；健全职责定位明确、风险控制有效、协调配合到位的市场监管体制，切实保护投资者合法权益。**三、进一步完善相关政策，促进资本市场稳定发展**资本市场的稳定发展需要相应的政策引导和⽀持。各部门要进⼀步完善相关政策，为资本市场稳定发展营造良好环境。完善证券发⾏上市核准制度。健全有利于各类优质企业平等利⽤资本市场的机制，提⾼资源配置效率。重视资本市场的投资回报。要采取切实措施，改变部分上市公司重上市、轻转制、重筹资、轻回报的状况，提⾼上市公司的整体质量，为投资者提供分享经济增长成果、增加财富的机会。⿎励合规资⾦⼊市。继续⼤⼒发展证券投资基⾦。⽀持保险资⾦以多种⽅式直接投资资本市场，逐步提⾼社会保障基⾦、企业补充养⽼基⾦、商业保险资⾦等投⼊资本市场的资⾦⽐例。要培养⼀批诚信、守法、专业的机构投资者，使基⾦管理公司和保险公司为主的机构投资者成为资本市场的主导⼒量。拓宽证券公司融资渠道。继续⽀持符合条件的证券公司公开发⾏股票或发⾏债券筹集长期资⾦。完善证券公司质押贷款及进⼊银⾏间同业市场管理办法，制定证券公司收购兼并和证券承销业务贷款的审核标准，在健全风险控制机制的前提下，为证券公司使⽤贷款融通资⾦创造有利条件。稳步开展基⾦管理公司融资试点。积极稳妥解决股权分置问题。规范上市公司⾮流通股份的转让⾏为，防⽌国有资产流失。稳步解决⽬前上市公司股份中尚不能上市流通股份的流通问题。在解决这⼀问题时要尊重市场规律，有利于市场的稳定和发展，切实保护投资者特别是公众投资者的合法权益。https://www.gov.cn/zhengce/content/2008-03/28/content_2071.htmPage3of8国务院关于推进资本市场改⾰开放和稳定发展的若⼲意⻅_宏观经济_中国政府⽹2025/9/12,10:38完善资本市场税收政策。研究制定⿎励社会公众投资的税收政策，完善证券、期货公司的流转税和所得税征收管理办法，对具备条件的证券、期货公司实⾏所得税集中征管。**四、健全资本市场体系，丰富证券投资品种**建⽴多层次股票市场体系。在统筹考虑资本市场合理布局和功能定位的基础上，逐步建⽴满⾜不同类型企业融资需求的多层次资本市场体系，研究提出相应的证券发⾏上市条件并建⽴配套的公司选择机制。继续规范和发展主板市场，逐步改善主板市场上市公司结构。分步推进创业板市场建设，完善风险投资机制，拓展中⼩企业融资渠道。积极探索和完善统⼀监管下的股份转让制度。积极稳妥发展债券市场。在严格控制风险的基础上，⿎励符合条件的企业通过发⾏公司债券筹集资⾦，改变债券融资发展相对滞后的状况，丰富债券市场品种，促进资本市场协调发展。制定和完善公司债券发⾏、交易、信息披露、信⽤评级等规章制度，建⽴健全资产抵押、信⽤担保等偿债保障机制。逐步建⽴集中监管、统⼀互联的债券市场。稳步发展期货市场。在严格控制风险的前提下，逐步推出为⼤宗商品⽣产者和消费者提供发现价格和套期保值功能的商品期货品种。建⽴以市场为主导的品种创新机制。研究开发与股票和债券相关的新品种及其衍⽣产品。加⼤风险较低的固定收益类证券产品的开发⼒度，为投资者提供储蓄替代型证券投资品种。积极探索并开发资产证券化品种。**五、进一步提高上市公司质量，推进上市公司规范运作**提⾼上市公司质量。上市公司的质量是证券市场投资价值的源泉。上市公司董事和⾼级管理⼈员要把股东利益最⼤化和不断提⾼盈https://www.gov.cn/zhengce/content/2008-03/28/content_2071.htmPage4of8国务院关于推进资本市场改⾰开放和稳定发展的若⼲意⻅_宏观经济_中国政府⽹2025/9/12,10:38利⽔平作为⼯作的出发点和落脚点。要进⼀步完善股票发⾏管理体制，推⾏证券发⾏上市保荐制度，⽀持竞争⼒强、运作规范、效益良好的公司发⾏上市，从源头上提⾼上市公司质量。⿎励已上市公司进⾏以市场为主导的、有利于公司持续发展的并购重组。进⼀步完善再融资政策，⽀持优质上市公司利⽤资本市场加快发展，做优做强。规范上市公司运作。完善上市公司法⼈治理结构，按照现代企业制度要求，真正形成权⼒机构、决策机构、监督机构和经营管理者之间的制衡机制。强化董事和⾼管⼈员的诚信责任，进⼀步完善独⽴董事制度。规范控股股东⾏为，对损害上市公司和中⼩股东利益的控股股东进⾏责任追究。强化上市公司及其他信息披露义务⼈的责任，切实保证信息披露的真实性、准确性、完整性和及时性。建⽴健全上市公司⾼管⼈员的激励约束机制。完善市场退出机制。要采取有效措施，结合多层次市场体系建设，进⼀步完善市场退出机制。在实现上市公司优胜劣汰的同时，建⽴对退市公司⾼管⼈员失职的责任追究机制，切实保护投资者的合法权益。**六、促进资本市场中介服务机构规范发展，提高执业水平**把证券、期货公司建设成为具有竞争⼒的现代⾦融企业。根据审慎监管原则，健全证券、期货公司的市场准⼊制度。督促证券、期货公司完善治理结构，规范其股东⾏为，强化董事会和经理⼈员的诚信责任。改⾰证券、期货客户交易结算资⾦管理制度，研究健全客户交易结算资⾦存管机制。严禁挪⽤客户资产，切实维护投资者合法权益。证券、期货公司要完善内控机制，加强对分⽀机构的集中统⼀管理。完善以净资本为核⼼的风险监控指标体系，督促证券、期货公司实施稳健的财务政策。⿎励证券、期货公司通过兼并重组、优化整合https://www.gov.cn/zhengce/content/2008-03/28/content_2071.htmPage5of8国务院关于推进资本市场改⾰开放和稳定发展的若⼲意⻅_宏观经济_中国政府⽹2025/9/12,10:38做优做强。建⽴健全证券、期货公司市场退出机制。加强对其他中介服务机构的管理。规范发展证券期货投资咨询机构、证券资信评级机构，加强对会计师事务所、律师事务所和资产评估机构的管理，提⾼中介机构的专业化服务⽔平。**七、加强法制和诚信建设，提高资本市场监管水平**健全资本市场法规体系，加强诚信建设。按照⼤⼒发展资本市场的总体部署，健全有利于资本市场稳定发展和投资者权益保护的法规体系。要清理阻碍市场发展的⾏政法规、地⽅性法规、部门规章以及政策性⽂件，为⼤⼒发展资本市场创建良好的法制环境。要按照健全现代市场经济社会信⽤体系的要求，制定资本市场诚信准则，维护诚信秩序，对严重违法违规、严重失信的机构和个⼈坚决实施市场禁⼊措施。推进依法⾏政，加强资本市场监管。按照深化⾏政审批制度改⾰和贯彻实施《⾏政许可法》的要求，提⾼执法⼈员的⾃⾝素质和执法⽔平。树⽴与时俱进的监管理念，建⽴健全与资本市场发展阶段相适应的监管⽅式，完善监管⼿段，提⾼监管效率。进⼀步充实监管⼒量，整合监管资源，培养⼀⽀政治素质和专业素质过硬的监管队伍。通过实施有效的市场监管，努⼒提⾼市场的公正性、透明度和效率，降低市场系统风险，保障市场参与者的合法权益。发挥⾏业⾃律和舆论监督作⽤。要发挥证券期货交易所、登记结算公司、证券期货业协会、律师、会计师、资产评估等⾏业协会的⾃律管理作⽤。要引导和加强新闻媒体对证券期货市场的宣传和监督。**八、加强协调配合，防范和化解市场风险**营造良好的资本市场发展环境。资本市场的风险防范关系到国家的⾦融安全和国民经济的健康发展。各地区、各部门都要关⼼和⽀持https://www.gov.cn/zhengce/content/2008-03/28/content_2071.htmPage6of8国务院关于推进资本市场改⾰开放和稳定发展的若⼲意⻅_宏观经济_中国政府⽹2025/9/12,10:38资本市场的规范发展，在出台涉及资本市场的政策措施时，要充分考虑资本市场的敏感性、复杂性和特殊性，并建⽴信息共享、沟通便捷、职责明确的协调配合机制，为市场稳定发展创造良好的环境和条件。共同防范和化解市场风险。各地区、各部门要切实履⾏《公司法》等有关法律法规规定的职责，采取有效措施防⽌和及时纠正发起⼈虚假出资、⼤股东或实际控制⼈侵占上市公司资产的⾏为；各地区和有关主管部门要依法加强对退市公司的管理，确保退市⼯作平稳顺利。对有重⼤经营风险必须退出资本市场或采取其他⾏政处置措施的证券、期货公司，地⽅⼈民政府、⾦融监管部门以及公安、司法等部门，要加强协调配合，按照法律法规和有关政策规定，采取积极有效措施做好风险处置⼯作。各地区、各部门必须建⽴应对资本市场突发事件的快速反应机制和防范化解风险的长效机制。严厉打击证券期货市场违法活动。各地区要贯彻落实国务院关于整顿和规范市场经济秩序的有关精神，严格禁⽌本地区⾮法发⾏证券、⾮法设⽴证券期货经营机构、⾮法代理证券期货买卖、⾮法或变相设⽴证券期货交易场所及其他证券期货违法活动。财政、公安、审计、⼯商等政府部门和国有资产监督管理机构要加强协调配合，加⼤打击⼒度，维护资本市场秩序。**九、认真总结经验，积极稳妥地推进对外开放**严格履⾏我国加⼊世贸组织关于证券服务业对外开放的承诺。⿎励具备条件的境外证券机构参股证券公司和基⾦管理公司，继续试⾏合格的境外机构投资者制度。积极利⽤境外资本市场。遵循市场规律和国际惯例，⽀持符合条件的内地企业到境外发⾏证券并上市。⽀持符合条件的内地机构和⼈https://www.gov.cn/zhengce/content/2008-03/28/content_2071.htmPage7of8国务院关于推进资本市场改⾰开放和稳定发展的若⼲意⻅_宏观经济_中国政府⽹2025/9/12,10:38员到境外从事与资本市场投资相关的服务业务和期货套期保值业务。认真研究合格的境内机构投资者制度。加强交流与合作。落实与⾹港、澳门更紧密经贸合作安排。进⼀步加强与相关国际组织及境外证券监管机构的联系与合作。⼤⼒发展资本市场是党中央、国务院从全局和战略出发作出的重要决策，各地区、各部门务必⾼度重视，树⽴全局观念，充分认识发展资本市场的重要性，坚定信⼼、抓住机遇、开拓创新，共同为资本市场发展创造条件，积极推动我国资本市场的改⾰开放和稳定发展，为实现全⾯建设⼩康社会的宏伟⽬标作出贡献。国务院⼆○○四年⼀⽉三⼗⼀⽇

name_chn: 2005年中央一号文件
text: **CPC Central Committee and State Council Opinions on Further Strengthening Rural Work and Raising Comprehensive Agricultural Production Capacity**  (December 31, 2004)The Party Central Committee and the State Council have always attached great importance to work concerning agriculture, rural areas, and farmers. In 2004, macro-control placed emphasis on strengthening agriculture, and a series of more direct and forceful policy measures were implemented. All regions and departments conscientiously carried out the central authorities’ decisions, protecting and mobilizing farmers’ enthusiasm and bringing about a sound development landscape in the countryside. Grain production registered an important turnaround; farmers’ incomes grew rapidly; rural reform made major strides; and rural social programs achieved fresh progress. This played a crucial role in promoting national economic development and maintaining social stability. At the same time, we must soberly recognize that agriculture remains the weak link in the national economy. Insufficient input and a fragile foundation have not changed; long-term mechanisms for boosting grain output and farmers’ incomes have not been established; deep-seated contradictions restraining agricultural and rural development have not been eliminated; and the pronounced lag in rural economic and social development has not been fundamentally reversed. Rural reform and development are still in a difficult uphill and tackle-the-tough-issues stage, and the task of maintaining the good momentum in rural development is extremely arduous.The overall requirements for agricultural and rural work in 2005 are: earnestly implement the spirit of the 16th National Congress of the CPC and the Third and Fourth Plenary Sessions of the 16th CPC Central Committee; fully put into practice the Scientific Outlook on Development; follow the strategy of coordinating urban–rural development; adhere to the principle of “giving more, taking less, and letting go”; stabilize, improve, and strengthen all policies supporting agriculture; effectively enhance the building of comprehensive agricultural production capacity; continue to adjust the structure of agriculture and the rural economy; further deepen rural reform; strive to achieve steady growth in grain production and sustained increases in farmers’ incomes; and promote comprehensive economic and social development in rural areas.Strengthening the agricultural foundation and revitalizing the rural economy require continued comprehensive measures. Now and for some time to come, we must treat as a major and urgent strategic task the strengthening of agricultural infrastructure, the acceleration of agricultural scientific and technological progress, and the improvement of comprehensive agricultural production capacity, and we must grasp these firmly. This is both the material foundation for ensuring national food security and a necessary condition for increasing farmers’ incomes; both an urgent need to address prominent contradictions in agricultural development and a strategic choice to enhance agriculture’s future momentum; both a major measure to advance the rural economy and an important guarantee for progress in rural society. Grasping this focus means grasping the key to agricultural development; getting this link right means getting to the root of agricultural modernization; doing this work well lays a solid foundation for building a moderately prosperous society in all respects in rural areas. We must further arouse farmers’ enthusiasm for farming and grain cultivation and local governments’ enthusiasm for prioritizing agriculture and grain, basing ourselves on strict farmland protection, focusing on strengthening farmland water conservancy, supporting progress in science and technology, and guaranteeing with sound service systems. After several years of effort, we should see significant improvements in the material and technological conditions of agriculture, marked increases in land yield and labor productivity, and notable enhancements in comprehensive agricultural efficiency and competitiveness.## I. Stabilize, improve, and strengthen policies that support agricultural development, and further mobilize farmers’ enthusiasm1) **Continue to step up implementation of the “two reductions and exemptions, three subsidies.”** Reducing and exempting the agricultural tax, abolishing the agricultural specialty tax (except on tobacco), granting direct subsidies to grain growers, and providing improved-seed and agricultural machinery purchase subsidies in some regions are major measures adopted by the CPC Central Committee and the State Council to strengthen agriculture and grain production. They are of great significance in motivating farmers to grow grain and in protecting and enhancing grain production capacity. These effective policies must not be altered; benefits to farmers must not be reduced; and support for agriculture must be continuously increased. Expand the scope of agricultural-tax exemptions and raise the intensity of tax reductions. In 2005, pilot abolition of the agricultural tax will be implemented in key national poverty-alleviation counties, and agricultural tax rates will be further lowered elsewhere. Pilot abolition of the animal husbandry tax will be carried out in pastoral areas. State-owned farm enterprises shall implement the same agricultural-tax reduction and exemption policies as where they are located. Local fiscal revenue reduced by agricultural (and animal husbandry) tax relief shall be partially compensated by special transfer payments from the central government. Where conditions permit, localities may independently pilot agricultural-tax exemptions. Continue providing direct subsidies to grain growers, with conditions-permitting localities further increasing subsidy intensity. The central government will continue to raise funding for improved-seed subsidies and agricultural machinery purchase subsidies; local governments shall also allocate appropriate funds based on local finances and agricultural needs. Continue implementing minimum purchase prices for key short-supplied grain varieties in major producing areas, and gradually establish and improve systems and mechanisms to stabilize grain market prices and protect grain farmers’ interests. Ensure supply and regulate markets for agricultural production materials; continue ex-factory price caps for chemical fertilizers; use tax measures to reasonably adjust fertilizer imports and exports and curb excessive price rises; and crack down hard on counterfeit and substandard inputs and all forms of predatory practices harming farmers.2) **Effectively strengthen support for major grain-producing areas.** To motivate local governments to develop grain production and to ease fiscal difficulties in central and western regions—especially counties and townships in major grain-producing areas—the central treasury shall, based on sown area, output, and commercial grain volume, provide rewards and subsidies to major grain-producing counties through transfer payments. Establish an interest coordination mechanism between major grain-producing and major grain-consuming areas; adjust the central subsidy ratio for the grain risk fund; and raise funds through other economic means to support production-capacity building in major grain-producing areas. Relevant departments shall promptly study and propose concrete implementation plans.3) **Establish stable, growing channels for funds supporting agriculture.** With determination, adjust the national income distribution structure. On the basis of stabilizing existing agricultural inputs, new fiscal expenditures and fixed-asset investment must tilt toward agriculture, rural areas, and farmers, gradually forming a stable growth mechanism for agricultural inputs. In view of weak farmland water conservancy urgently needing reinforcement, from 2005 onward, in addition to continuing construction of large and medium-sized farmland water conservancy infrastructure, inputs into small-scale farmland water conservancy shall be steadily increased. On the basis of integrating relevant special funds, the central and provincial treasuries shall allocate a portion of newly increased budgetary revenue to set up special subsidy funds for small-scale farmland water conservancy, supporting households’ labor contributions to build such works. Budgetary regular capital construction investment and treasury-bond funds shall increase allocations to small-scale farmland water conservancy projects. The portion of land transfer fees used for agricultural land development and revenue from paid use of newly added construction land shall, together with land development and consolidation, allocate certain funds for small-scale water conservancy. Municipal and county governments must also increase investment. Legislation should be advanced expeditiously to institutionalize and standardize major agricultural support policies.## II. Firmly implement the strictest arable-land protection system and truly improve land quality4) **Strictly protect arable land.** Control non-agricultural land occupation; ensure that the total area, quality, and designated use of basic farmland do not diminish, and implement this down to specific plots and households. It is strictly forbidden to dig ponds for fish farming, plant trees, or conduct other activities that damage the tillage layer on basic farmland. Revise the Interim Regulations on Farmland Occupation Tax and raise tax rates, strictly controlling reductions and exemptions. Improve township land-use master planning and village/town planning to guide intensive rural land use. Strengthen management of collective construction land and rural homesteads; encourage land consolidation and village renovation; promote new rural industries to cluster in townships; and raise overall land-use efficiency. Accelerate reform of rural land expropriation and requisition systems.5) **Conscientiously implement rural land-contracting policies.** In response to practices in some places of arbitrarily reclaiming farmers’ contracted land and forcing land transfer, all localities shall comprehensively review implementation of the second-round land contracts; resolutely correct violations of law and policy and hold those responsible to account. Properly handle land-contract disputes and resolve conflicts in a timely manner to safeguard farmers’ lawful rights and interests. Respect and protect farmers’ rights to contracted land and to engage in agricultural production, including migrant workers’ land-contract rights and operational autonomy. Transfers of contracted-operation rights and appropriately scaled operations must be conducted lawfully on a voluntary and compensated basis, avoiding one-sided pursuits of land concentration. Provinces, autonomous regions, and municipalities shall promptly formulate implementation measures for the Rural Land Contracting Law.6) **Work hard to build soil fertility.** The central and provincial treasuries shall substantially increase inputs for comprehensive agricultural development, with new funds concentrated in major grain-producing areas for transforming medium- and low-yield fields and building high-standard basic farmland. Implement the “Fertile Soil Project,” expand inputs, strengthen soil-fertility surveys and monitoring, and establish a nationwide dynamic monitoring and early-warning system for arable-land quality to guide scientific cultivation. Reform traditional tillage methods and develop conservation agriculture. Promote soil-testing–based formula fertilization, comprehensive utilization and harmless treatment of organic fertilizers, encourage greater application of farmyard manure, and raise soil organic matter.## III. Strengthen farmland water conservancy and ecological development to boost resilience against natural disasters7) **Accelerate continued construction and upgrading of large irrigation districts with a focus on water-saving retrofits.** New fixed-asset investment shall prioritize these upgrades with steadily rising inputs, focusing on on-farm works, replacing aging electromechanical equipment, and improving irrigation and drainage systems. Pilot construction of terminal canal systems in districts under continued construction. Continue advancing water-saving irrigation demonstrations and pilot scaled construction in major grain-producing areas. Where conditions permit, accelerate rural water-conservancy modernization. Areas with favorable water sources should expand irrigated area alongside key water-hub projects; arid areas should develop water-saving dryland agriculture and continue building demonstration zones. Strengthen measurement of irrigation water and actively implement total-use controls and quota management. From 2005 onward, pilot subsidies for farmers purchasing water-saving equipment in selected regions. Continue reinforcement of dangerous reservoirs and advance local medium-scale water sources and treatment of small and medium rivers.8) **Vigorously promote small-scale farmland water-conservancy construction.** Prioritize on-farm irrigation and drainage, small irrigation districts, and drought-resistant water sources in non-irrigated areas. Step up treatment of salinization and waterlogging in medium- and low-yield fields in major producing areas. Accelerate rainwater harvesting and utilization in hilly/mountainous and other arid regions. Local governments must assume responsibility for this work. While resolutely abolishing labor-accumulation and compulsory-labor systems on schedule, explore new mechanisms and methods for farmland capital works under new conditions. Clearly distinguish between increasing farmers’ burdens and farmers’ voluntary labor to improve their own production and living conditions. On the basis of strengthened democratic decision-making and management, and under principles of voluntariness, mutual benefit, practical results, controlled standards, and strict norms, guide farmers to contribute labor to small-scale facilities from which they directly benefit. The state shall provide appropriate subsidies for materials needed for micro water-works built by farmers; relevant departments shall promptly formulate specific measures.9) **Unswervingly advance key ecological projects.** Continue natural-forest protection and improve supporting policies. Return-to-forest work must be scientifically planned, focused, pragmatic, and steadily advanced. Take effective measures to build basic staple-grain fields in areas of return-to-forest, cultivate follow-on industries, and genuinely solve farmers’ long-term livelihoods, consolidating achievements. Strengthen shelterbelts and farmland shelter-networks to create ecological barriers for high-standard farmland. Earnestly advance desertification control, including the Beijing–Tianjin sandstorm source control project. Continue comprehensive development in mountainous areas. Further strengthen grassland development and protection, accelerate “return grazing to grassland,” build pastoral water-works, and enhance forest and grassland fire control and pest control. Carry out soil and water conservation in key basins such as the Yangtze and Yellow Rivers; promote small-watershed governance using check dams and other measures; and strengthen comprehensive treatment in southern red-soil hills, northeastern black-soil rolling areas, and karst rocky desertification zones in the southwest. Effectively prevent and control agricultural and water pollution.## IV. Accelerate agricultural S&T innovation and raise technological content10) **Strengthen innovation capacity.** Substantially increase inputs in agricultural research; accelerate establishment of a diversified funding system led by government with broad social participation and a stable growth mechanism. Raise the share of national S&T spending going to agriculture, and significantly increase agricultural research funding within major S&T projects and programs. Deepen reform of the agricultural research system and quickly establish a national agricultural S&T innovation system. Strengthen state bases’ innovation capacity; carry out basic and key-technology research; and accelerate research on high technologies such as biotechnology and IT. Based on national agro-ecological zoning and resource integration, build regional agricultural research centers relying on strong provincial institutes and universities to drive regional innovation and conduct major applied R&D and trials. Strengthen national laboratories, breeding centers, engineering centers, and key laboratories in agriculture; improve facilities and equipment; and speed the building of high-level talent training bases.11) **Increase dissemination of improved varieties and practices.** Continue the “Seed Project” and the “Livestock and Aquatic Breeding Project,” and build and expand bases for major crop and livestock breeding and extension. From 2005, launch a super-rice extension project. Expand special subsidies for major agricultural technology extension, prioritizing development of integrated, high-yield, quality-improving, and cost-saving technologies. Strengthen control of major crop pests and diseases. Organize the “Science and Technology to Households” program, support demonstration households, and raise their spillover impact. Continue allocating funds for S&T result transformation and for introducing advanced foreign agricultural technologies.12) **Accelerate reform of the agricultural technology-extension system.** In line with strengthening public-service functions and invigorating commercial services, intensify reform. Public agricultural extension institutions shall mainly undertake introduction, trial, and demonstration of key technologies; monitoring, forecasting, prevention, and response for crop pests, animal diseases, and agricultural disasters; compulsory inspections and monitoring of quality and safety in production; monitoring of agricultural resources, ecology, and input use; water-resource management and flood/drought response; and public information and training services. Fiscal authorities at all levels shall guarantee funding for public extension. Meanwhile, general extension and commercial services shall be steadily separated and operated on market principles. Give full play to agricultural colleges in extension; foster farmers’ technical associations and agri-tech enterprises. Explore new mechanisms, employ bidding for extension projects, and encourage various organizations and firms to compete fairly. On the basis of pilots, relevant departments shall promptly issue guidance on strengthening extension-system development.## V. Strengthen rural infrastructure and improve the environment for agricultural development13) **Increase investment in small rural infrastructure.** Continue expanding the “six small projects” (drinking water for people and livestock, rural roads, rural biogas, small hydropower, grassland fencing, etc.), broaden coverage, and raise quality. On the basis of consolidating achievements in solving drinking-water difficulties, attach great importance to rural drinking-water safety, addressing issues in high-fluoride, high-arsenic, brackish/saline-water, and schistosomiasis areas; relevant departments shall promptly formulate plans. Adjust highway investment structure to boost rural roads, and coordinate standards, quality, and maintenance with reasonable subsidy benchmarks. Accelerate rural energy development—continue rural biogas, and actively develop solar, wind, and other clean and renewable energies. Expand “small hydropower as fuel substitute,” and strengthen follow-up construction and operation of rural grid upgrades. Increase poverty-alleviation inputs for rural infrastructure in poor areas; guide farmers to build water works, improve soils, and construct roads; implement village-wide poverty-reduction plans; improve mechanisms; and speed up poverty exit.14) **Accelerate construction of agricultural distribution and inspection/testing facilities.** While continuing to improve fairs and wholesale markets, leverage futures markets’ guiding role; encourage modern logistics, chain operations, and e-commerce. Upgrade wholesale markets; develop broker agency, auctions, and online trading to enhance trading functions. Speed construction of cold-chain systems centered on cold storage and refrigerated transport; treat land for such storage as industrial land. Give play to supply-and-marketing cooperatives in distribution and input supply. Encourage the postal system to offer direct rural delivery and distribution services. Strengthen agricultural informatization; meteorology shall better serve agriculture. Provinces shall open green channels for whole-vehicle transport of perishable produce, implement toll reductions or exemptions, and quickly connect inter-provincially. Advance agricultural standardization. Strengthen inspection/testing infrastructure, raise quarantine equipment and testing levels for imports/exports, and enhance defenses against invasive species. Strengthen agricultural product quality and safety, implement certification and accreditation, ban production/sale/use of highly toxic, high-residue pesticides, and accelerate legislation on quality and safety.15) **Strengthen comprehensive supporting systems for agricultural development.** Build seven systems: improved seeds and breeds; S&T innovation and application; plant and animal protection; agricultural product quality and safety; market information; agricultural resources and ecological protection; and agricultural socialized services and management. Relevant departments shall quickly develop plans, strengthen policy guidance, clarify responsibilities, increase inputs through multiple channels, and accelerate construction.## VI. Continue advancing adjustment of agricultural and rural economic structures to raise competitiveness16) **Further promote grain production.** Adhere to the principle of basic self-sufficiency through domestic supply; be guided by market demand; improve variety structure and optimize regional layout; focus on yield; and strive to maintain overall supply–demand balance. Stabilize and increase sown area; reform cropping systems; and raise multiple-cropping indexes. Implement the high-quality grain industry project; build commercial-grain bases; and develop high-quality grain belts. Strengthen services in technology, machinery, information, and marketing; ensure breeding and supply of improved varieties; and promote cost-reducing, efficiency-enhancing production. Improve and implement the provincial governor responsibility system for grain; major consuming and balanced provinces must also do a good job in grain production, ensure necessary reserves, and stabilize markets.17) **Vigorously develop specialty agriculture.** Leverage regional comparative advantages, build agricultural industry belts, and develop specialty agriculture. Based on resource endowments, select varieties with local characteristics and market prospects as focal points to quickly form competitive industries. Localities and departments shall formulate plans and policies to accelerate development. Build standardized demonstration bases; screen and propagate fine varieties; integrate traditional methods with modern technology; and raise quality and production levels. Strengthen protection of specialty products; advance origin labeling; safeguard producers’ rights. Integrate and cultivate brands and support building well-known products. Enhance international competitiveness, promote exports of advantageous products, and expand agricultural opening-up.18) **Accelerate development of animal husbandry.** A robust livestock sector is essential to comprehensive agricultural capacity. In pastoral areas, advance fenced, rotational, and resting grazing; develop forage fields; improve breeds; and ease overgrazing pressure. In farming areas, fully utilize crop straw and abundant labor to develop grain-saving livestock models and raise scale and intensification. Use micro-credit and interest subsidies to guide development of livestock clusters where conditions permit. Increase investment to support clusters in building waste and wastewater treatment. From 2005, implement subsidies for dairy breed improvement. Speed establishment of safe, high-quality, and efficient feed systems. Animal disease prevention is fundamental to stable development, public health, and safety; increase inputs, improve systems, and strengthen capacity. Quickly plan the animal disease-prevention system and accelerate building of major disease surveillance and early warning, prevention and control, inspection and quarantine supervision, veterinary drug quality oversight and residue monitoring, technical support, and material-guarantee systems. Accelerate technical upgrades at key veterinary biologics producers. Quickly build disease-control teams; include personnel and operating funds of animal-quarantine supervision agencies in government budgets at all levels.19) **Prioritize support for agro-processing in major grain-producing areas.** Vigorously support the food-processing industry, especially grain-based processing in major producing areas. These areas should leverage local advantages, take agro-processing as a breakthrough, follow a new-type industrialization path, and promote higher agricultural efficiency, farmer incomes, and regional development. Provide interest subsidies and other measures to support technology introduction/retrofit and storage capacity building. Improve VAT policies for agro-processing and, in line with overall VAT transformation plans, accelerate transformation for food and other agro-processing.20) **Develop agricultural industrialization.** Continue strengthening support for leading agribusinesses of diverse ownership and operating forms. Encourage various benefit-sharing linkages with bases and farmers. The Agricultural Bank of China and other state-owned commercial banks, in accordance with regulations, shall improve credit services to leaders and ease seasonal purchase-fund strains. The Agricultural Development Bank may lend to leading enterprises focusing on grain, cotton, and oil production, circulation, or processing. Explore effective approaches whereby leaders and cooperatives take on, guarantee, or service farmers’ loans. Support farmer professional cooperatives and appropriately reduce or exempt relevant taxes and fees on them and their processing/distribution entities. Collective economic organizations shall build strength, deliver services, and—together with other cooperatives—serve as bridges between leading firms and farmers. Township enterprises shall accelerate structural adjustment, technological progress, and institutional innovation and actively participate in agricultural industrialization.## VII. Reform and improve rural investment and financing, and perfect agricultural input mechanisms21) **Improve the agricultural investment management system.** Further open investment fields in agriculture and rural infrastructure; use interest subsidies, grants, and tax measures to guide state funds and encourage social capital to invest. Gradually lower counterpart funding ratios for agricultural fixed-asset projects in central and western regions, and do not raise counterpart funds by increasing farmers’ burdens. Strengthen integration of state agricultural funds; encourage county-level integration through planning, overall arrangements, clear responsibilities, and project leverage to improve efficiency. For state-invested/subsidized village projects, accelerate implementation of disclosure, tendering, fund tracking, and post-evaluation to ensure sound fund use and project quality.22) **Speed reform of property-rights systems for small rural infrastructure.** On the basis of experience, clarify property rights and responsibilities to fully mobilize investment and management enthusiasm. For micro projects built or mainly used by households, ownership belongs to individuals, with certificates issued by township governments. For projects with many beneficiaries, establish cooperative management bodies with state-subsidized assets owned by cooperatives. For commercial projects, establish corporate entities for market-based operations or auction to individuals. Local governments should support privately developed rural infrastructure and regulate fees and services. Accelerate reform in the management of small rural water-works. Reforms must respect farmers’ wishes and protect original beneficiaries’ rights.23) **Advance rural financial reform and innovation.** Tailored to rural financial needs, accelerate building a rural financial system with complete functions, clear division of labor, clarified property rights, and strong supervision. Quickly develop an overall reform plan. Deepen rural credit-cooperative reform to improve governance, strengthen constraints, and bolster support to agriculture—so they remain the mainstay. Formulate policies within counties defining each financial institution’s obligations to support “agriculture, rural areas, and farmers” and specify the proportion of incremental deposits at and below the county level used locally. Guide postal savings funds collected at and below county level to flow back to rural areas. Strengthen policy-based finance, increase medium- and long-term lending to agriculture/rural development, reinforce the Agricultural Development Bank’s role, and expand its scope. The Agricultural Bank shall continue to support agriculture and serve rural areas. Cultivate competitive rural financial markets; promptly set entry and supervision rules for new multi-ownership rural financial institutions and launch pilots under effective risk control. Where conditions permit, explore microcredit organizations initiated by natural persons or enterprises that are close to farmers’ needs. Implement diversified collateral/guarantee policies for farm households and SMEs. Expand pilots of agricultural policy insurance and encourage commercial insurers to offer agricultural insurance.## VIII. Raise the quality of rural labor and promote comprehensive rural social development24) **Carry out comprehensive vocational-skills training for farmers.** In keeping with structure adjustment, specialty agriculture, and production needs, conduct practical, effective, and accessible training in agricultural technology. Rural secondary schools should also strengthen instruction in advanced practical technologies. To support industrial upgrading and competitiveness, advance re-employment and job-transfer training, expand the “Sunshine Project” for rural labor transfer, and speed labor mobility. Finance at all levels shall substantially increase training inputs, using subsidies, training vouchers, and reimbursement systems to improve practicality and efficiency. Mobilize broad social participation.25) **Further develop rural education, health, culture, and other social programs.** Implement the requirement that incremental funding in education, health, culture, and family planning be used mainly in rural areas, with at least 70% below the county level. By 2007, strive to ensure all poor rural students in compulsory education enjoy textbook-fee and miscellaneous-fee waivers and boarding subsidies; national key poverty counties shall accelerate progress. Uphold a rural-focused health policy; steadily advance the new rural cooperative medical system and medical assistance; implement plans for rural health infrastructure; train rural health personnel; and improve services and emergency response. Strengthen prevention and control of HIV/AIDS, schistosomiasis, and other key diseases, and promote comprehensive rural environmental sanitation improvements such as safe water and toilets. Improve rural family planning; implement reward and assistance policies for some rural families; and advance the “Have Fewer Children to Get Rich” pilot. Where conditions permit, explore rural social security systems. Increase major rural cultural projects,完善 public cultural services, and encourage social participation. Consolidate rural publicity and cultural positions and regulate rural cultural markets. Raise the coverage and quality of the “Village-to-Village” radio/TV program, and advance book delivery to the countryside, film screenings, and cultural information-sharing projects.## IX. Strengthen and improve the Party’s leadership over rural work26) **Always take resolving agriculture, rural, and farmer issues as the top priority of the whole Party’s work.** This is a major long-term policy during industrialization, urbanization, and modernization. Party members—especially leading cadres at all levels—must deeply recognize the long-term, complex, and arduous nature of “three rural” work. Even amid favorable trends of rising grain and incomes, we must remain clear-headed; there must be no slackening. In line with the stage of industrialization and policy orientation, and in accordance with the requirement that industry feed back to agriculture and cities support the countryside, we must integrate agricultural and rural economic development into overall national planning, more consciously adjust income distribution, more proactively strengthen agriculture’s basic position, and intensify rural reform, agricultural support, and leadership over “three rural” work.27) **Further strengthen Party building in rural areas.** Conscientiously implement the spirit of the Fourth Plenum of the 16th CPC Central Committee; in keeping with the advanced-education campaign, deepen the “three-level joint creation” activities for rural Party building; enhance creativity, cohesion, and combat effectiveness of grassroots Party organizations; fully play their core leadership role; and further consolidate the Party’s rural governing base. Step up education and training for rural Party cadres; expand distance-education pilots; strengthen service consciousness and integrity; transform work styles; and improve ability to implement policy, act according to law, develop the economy, and maintain stability, establishing a good image. Care for grassroots cadres and help solve their difficulties. Expand grassroots democracy;完善 village affairs openness, government transparency, and democratic management; establish a vibrant villager autonomy mechanism led by village Party organizations; and effectively safeguard peasants’ democratic rights. Advance rural rule of law, strengthen legal education, and improve comprehensive agricultural law enforcement. Do mass work under new conditions, properly handle social contradictions, care for the needy, and foster a harmonious social atmosphere. Strengthen comprehensive rural public-security management, and punish crimes according to law. Advance mass spiritual-civilization activities, and guide farmers to work hard and be self-reliant, speeding the building of a moderately prosperous society in all respects.Further strengthening rural work, raising comprehensive agricultural production capacity, and achieving higher grain output, greater agricultural efficiency, and higher farmer incomes are of great significance and entail arduous tasks. Let us unite more closely around the CPC Central Committee with Comrade Hu Jintao as General Secretary, hold high the great banners of Deng Xiaoping Theory and the Important Thought of the “Three Represents,” strengthen confidence, forge ahead, and work hard to fully accomplish all tasks in agriculture and rural work.
