text: # Grain Prices Likely to Remain Elevated Over the Next DecadeIn June 2010, the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) and the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) released the *Agricultural Outlook 2010–2019*, stating that average global grain prices are expected to remain at relatively high levels over the next decade and that the global food security situation remains worrisome.The report issued by the OECD and FAO notes that average global grain prices are projected to stay relatively high over the next ten years and that food security remains a concern.According to the report’s projections, over the next decade the average prices of wheat and coarse grains will be **15% to 40% higher** than their average levels during 1997–2006 (inflation-adjusted, in real terms). The real prices of vegetable oils are expected to increase by **40%**. The average price increases for dairy products are projected to range between **16% and 45%**.The report states that, compared with the past decade, the growth rate of global agricultural output will slow, but will still maintain a certain pace. Brazil will be among the fastest-growing producers, with output expected to increase by **more than 40%** between now and 2019. Output in China, India, the Russian Federation, and Ukraine is also expected to rise by **over 20%**.The report further points out that, although global food production is sufficient to feed the world’s population, the recent price spikes and the economic crisis have further worsened hunger and food insecurity. About **one billion people** worldwide are undernourished. If food prices remain high, food security will be further undermined—especially for the poor, who spend the bulk of their income on food—imposing even greater hardship. However, the report adds that establishing a well-regulated and effective trading system would foster fair competition and ensure that food moves from surplus to deficit regions.Analyzing the causes of **price volatility**, the report concludes that recent turmoil has disrupted agricultural markets, including fluctuations in grain output and stocks, swings in oil prices, and the global economic recession. While short-term price volatility is currently elevated, there is no conclusive evidence that the long-term price trends for major grains have fundamentally changed. The extent to which world price movements affect domestic markets varies markedly across countries. Price transmission depends on several factors, notably a country’s integration with world markets, its infrastructure, and—most importantly—its trade and agricultural policies.Presenting the *Agricultural Outlook 2010–2019* in Rome, OECD Secretary-General **Angel Gurría** and FAO Director-General **Jacques Diouf** said that the agricultural sector had demonstrated resilience in the face of recent price shocks and the economic downturn. Overall, this year’s cautiously formulated outlook is the most positive in several years. Nonetheless, governments should take further measures to ensure that farmers have access to more effective risk-management tools—such as production contracts, insurance schemes, and the use of futures markets—to hedge against risks.
text_chn: 未来⼗年粮⻝价格将居⾼2025/9/12,10:44**中⽂**English⽆障碍2025年9⽉12⽇星期五农历本⽉23⽇秋分农业农村部邮箱请输⼊关键字搜索**司局介绍****⼯作动态****通知公告****“****⼀带⼀路****”****合作和农业⾛出去农业国际贸易监测与展望多双边合作**当前位置：⾸页>机构>国际合作司>⼯作动态**未来⼗年粮⾷价格将居⾼**⽇期：2010-06-28作者：来源：常驻联合国粮农机构代表处【字号：⼤中⼩】打印本页2010年6⽉，经合组织和粮农组织发布的《2010-2019年农业展望》报告中指出，未来⼗年世界平均粮⾷价格将居较⾼⽔平，粮⾷安全状况仍令⼈担忧。和粮农组织发布的报告中指出，未来⼗年世界平均粮⾷价格将居较⾼⽔平，粮⾷安全状况仍令⼈担忧。报告预测，在未来⼗年⾥，⼩麦和粗粮的平均价格将⽐1997-2006年期间的平均⽔平上涨15%⾄40%（通胀调整后的实际价格）。植物油的实际价格预计将上涨40%。奶制品价格的平均涨幅将在16%⾄45%之间。报告说，与过去⼗年相⽐，未来⼗年全球农业产出的增长速度将会放缓，但仍会保持⼀定的增速。巴西将是⽬前增速更快的国家，预计其产量从现在到2019年将增长40%以上。中国、印度、俄罗斯联邦和乌克兰的产量增幅预计也将超过20%。报告还指出，尽管全球⽣产的粮⾷能够养活其⼈⼜，但最近出现的价格飙升和经济危机导致饥饿和粮⾷不安全状况进⼀步恶化。全球约有10亿⼈营养不良。如果⾷品价格持续⾼涨，将会进⼀步影响粮⾷安全，尤其对于穷⼈，他们将⼤部分收⼊⽤于购买粮⾷，带给他们的将是更⼤地困难。然⽽，报告称，建⽴⼀个规范有效的贸易体系将有利于公平竞争，确保粮⾷从剩余地区输送到缺粮地区。报告分析价格波动原因，认为主要由于近期发⽣的动荡，扰乱了农产品市场，其中包括粮⾷产量和库存的⾼低变化、⽯油价格波动、全球经济衰退等。报告认为，虽然⽬前短期的价格波动较⼤，但并⽆决定性的证据说明主要粮⾷作物的长期价格⾛向已出现变化。世界价格的变化幅度对各国国内市场的影响差异极⼤。价格传导取决于若⼲因素，即⼀个国家与世界市场的⼀体化、基础设施和通常最重要的贸易和农业政策。经合组织秘书长安吉尔·古利亚与粮农组织总⼲事迪乌夫在罗马介绍《2010-2019年农业展望》时说，农业部门在最近出现的价格冲击和经济衰退中显⽰了其恢复⼒。总的来看，今年审慎做出的农业展望是近⼏年来最为积极的。但未来各国政府还应当采取措施，确保农民掌握更加有效的风险管理⼿段，掌握⽣产合同，利⽤保险计划和期货市场规避风险等。机关⼦站直属单位⽹站国务院各部门⽹站地⽅农业管理部门⽹站关于我们|⽹站声明|⽹站地图|联系我们|访问分析主办单位：中华⼈民共和国农业农村部承办单位：农业农村部信息中⼼⽹站识别码bm21000007京ICP备05039419号-2最佳浏览器模式：1024*768分辨率京公⽹安备11010502037559号https://gjs.moa.gov.cn/gzdt/201006/t20100628_1589067.htmPage1of2未来⼗年粮⻝价格将居⾼2025/9/12,10:44京公⽹安备11010502037559号⽹站保留所有权，未经允许不得复制镜像https://gjs.moa.gov.cn/gzdt/201006/t20100628_1589067.htmPage2of2

name_chn: 期货交易所管理办法（证监期货字〔1999〕43号）
text: # Measures for the Administration of Futures Exchanges(CSRC Futures [1999] No. 43)---# Chapter I  General Provisions**Article 1**  For the purpose of strengthening the administration of futures exchanges, clarifying their powers and responsibilities, preventing market risks, and maintaining the normal order of the futures market, these Measures are formulated in accordance with the *Interim Regulations on the Administration of Futures Trading*.**Article 2**  These Measures apply to futures exchanges established within the territory of the People’s Republic of China.**Article 3**  A “futures exchange” as referred to in these Measures means a legal person established in accordance with the conditions prescribed by the *Interim Regulations on the Administration of Futures Trading* and these Measures, that is non-profit in nature, performs the functions stipulated in the *Interim Regulations on the Administration of Futures Trading* and these Measures, and implements self-regulation pursuant to its articles of association.**Article 4**  The China Securities Regulatory Commission (hereinafter, the “CSRC”) shall, in accordance with law, exercise centralized and unified supervision and administration over futures exchanges.---# Chapter II  Establishment, Change, and Termination**Article 5**  The establishment of a futures exchange shall be subject to the approval of the CSRC. Without such approval, no entity or individual may establish, or in a disguised form establish, a futures exchange.  The name of a futures exchange shall include the wording “Commodity Exchange” or “Futures Exchange.” No other entity or individual may use the wording “Commodity Exchange,” “Futures Exchange,” or words of similar meaning.**Article 6**  The registered capital of a futures exchange shall be divided into equal shares as membership fees, to be subscribed by members.  The equity of a futures exchange shall be jointly enjoyed by its members and, during the period of the exchange’s existence, may not be distributed to members from the accumulation thereof.**Article 7**  A futures exchange shall perform the following functions:  (1) Provide venues, facilities, and related services for futures trading;  (2) Formulate and implement the business rules of the exchange;  (3) Design futures contracts and arrange for their listing;  (4) Organize and supervise futures trading, settlement, and delivery;  (5) Formulate and implement risk management systems and control market risks;  (6) Ensure the performance of futures contracts;  (7) Publish market information;  (8) Supervise the futures business of members and inspect members’ illegal or irregular acts;  (9) Supervise the futures business of designated delivery warehouses;  (10) Other functions as prescribed by the CSRC.**Article 8**  A futures exchange shall not engage in trust investment, stock trading, investment in non-self-use real estate, or other businesses unrelated to its functions; except for providing performance guarantees for the fulfillment of futures contracts, it shall not provide guarantees for other entities or individuals; nor shall it publish texts or materials forecasting futures prices.  A futures exchange is prohibited from directly or indirectly participating in futures trading.**Article 9**  An applicant for establishing a futures exchange shall submit the following documents and materials to the CSRC:  (1) An application letter;  (2) Draft articles of association and trading rules;  (3) The business plan of the futures exchange;  (4) A list of prospective members of the exchange;  (5) A list and résumés of candidates for the council (board of directors);  (6) Supporting documents and explanatory materials regarding premises, equipment, and funds;  (7) A list and résumés of proposed senior management personnel;  (8) Other documents and materials as required by the CSRC.**Article 10**  The articles of association of a futures exchange shall specify the following matters:  (1) Purpose of establishment and functions;  (2) Name, domicile, and place of business;  (3) Registered capital and the members’ capital contributions;  (4) Term of operation;  (5) Acquisition of membership;  (6) Rights and obligations of members;  (7) Establishment of organizational bodies, their powers, and rules of procedure;  (8) Selection, appointment and removal of management personnel, and their duties;  (9) Basic business rules;  (10) Risk reserve fund administration system;  (11) Financial accounting and internal audit systems;  (12) Conditions and procedures for change and termination, and methods of liquidation;  (13) Procedures for amending the articles of association;  (14) Other matters that need to be provided for in the articles of association.**Article 11**  The trading rules of a futures exchange shall specify the following matters:  (1) Trading venue and hours;  (2) Listed products and futures contracts;  (3) Procedures for suspension, resumption, and cancellation of futures contract trading;  (4) Management system for the trading floor;  (5) Rules for brokerage and proprietary trading;  (6) Risk control system and procedures for handling abnormal trading situations;  (7) Systems for futures settlement and delivery;  (8) Systems for the administration and use of margin;  (9) Methods for publishing futures trading information;  (10) Violations and defaults and measures for handling them;  (11) Methods for handling trading disputes;  (12) Other matters that need to be specified in the trading rules.**Article 12**  Mergers and divisions of futures exchanges shall be subject to the examination and approval of the CSRC.  A merger of futures exchanges may take the form of absorption or the establishment of a new exchange; the rights and obligations of the parties prior to the merger shall be succeeded to by the surviving or newly established futures exchange.  Where a futures exchange is divided, its rights and obligations shall be succeeded to by the futures exchanges resulting from the division.**Article 13**  Without the approval of the CSRC, a futures exchange shall not establish branches or any other futures trading venues.**Article 14**  Where any of the following changes occurs, a futures exchange shall obtain the approval of the CSRC:  (1) Change of name;  (2) Change of domicile or place of business;  (3) Other changes as prescribed by the CSRC.**Article 15**  A futures exchange shall be terminated under any of the following circumstances:  (1) The term of operation as provided in the articles of association expires and the members’ general assembly decides not to extend it;  (2) The members’ general assembly decides to dissolve the exchange;  (3) Dissolution due to merger or division;  (4) The CSRC decides to close the exchange.  Where a futures exchange is dissolved under items (1), (2), or (3) of the preceding paragraph, such dissolution shall be subject to the approval of the CSRC.  Upon termination of a futures exchange, a liquidation group shall be formed to conduct liquidation. The liquidation plan formulated by the liquidation group shall be submitted to the CSRC for approval.**Article 16**  Where a futures exchange is terminated, the CSRC shall make a public announcement. Members of the futures exchange shall settle all futures trading business within 90 days from the date of announcement.---# Chapter III  Organizational Structure**Article 17**  A futures exchange shall establish a members’ general assembly and a council.**Article 18**  The members’ general assembly is the authority of the futures exchange and is composed of all members.  The members’ general assembly shall exercise the following powers:  (1) Adopt the articles of association and trading rules of the exchange and draft amendments thereto;  (2) Elect and remove member directors;  (3) Deliberate on and approve the work reports of the council and the general manager;  (4) Deliberate on and approve the budgets and final accounts of the exchange;  (5) Deliberate on the use of the exchange’s risk reserve fund;  (6) Decide on increases or decreases of the exchange’s registered capital;  (7) Decide on matters relating to merger, division, dissolution, and liquidation of the exchange;  (8) Decide on other major matters submitted by the council;  (9) Other powers provided in the articles of association of the exchange.**Article 19**  The members’ general assembly shall be convened by the council and, in general, shall be held once a year.  An extraordinary members’ meeting shall be convened under any of the following circumstances:  (1) The number of member directors falls below the minimum number prescribed by these Measures or below two-thirds of the number specified in the articles of association;  (2) A joint proposal by more than one-third of the members;  (3) The council deems it necessary.**Article 20**  Meetings of the members’ general assembly shall be presided over by the chair of the council. Where the chair is, for special reasons, unable to perform duties, a vice-chair designated by the chair or another director shall preside. Members shall be informed of the matters to be deliberated no later than 30 days before the meeting is held. An extraordinary members’ meeting shall not adopt resolutions on matters not listed in the notice.**Article 21**  A meeting of the members’ general assembly shall be valid only if more than two-thirds of the members are present, and each member shall have one vote.  Resolutions of the members’ general assembly shall be adopted by a vote of more than one-half of all members. Resolutions on merger, division, dissolution and liquidation of the exchange, or on increases or decreases of the exchange’s registered capital, shall be adopted by a vote of more than two-thirds of all members.**Article 22**  A member shall attend the members’ general assembly through its legal representative.  If the legal representative is unable to attend, the member may authorize a proxy to attend the meeting. The proxy shall submit a power of attorney to the exchange and exercise voting rights within the scope of authorization.**Article 23**  Minutes shall be kept for voting matters at the members’ general assembly and shall be signed by the directors present at the meeting.  Within three days after the end of the meeting, the exchange shall file all meeting documents with the CSRC for the record.**Article 24**  The council is the standing body of the members’ general assembly and is responsible to it.  The council shall exercise the following powers:  (1) Convene meetings of the members’ general assembly and report on its work thereto;  (2) Supervise the implementation of the resolutions of the members’ general assembly and the council;  (3) Supervise the performance of duties by the general manager;  (4) Draft the articles of association, trading rules, and amendments thereto, and submit them to the members’ general assembly for adoption;  (5) Deliberate on the budgets and final accounts proposed by the general manager and submit them to the members’ general assembly for adoption;  (6) Deliberate on plans for merger, division, dissolution, and liquidation of the exchange and submit them to the members’ general assembly for adoption;  (7) Decide on the establishment of specialized committees;  (8) Decide on the admission of members;  (9) Decide on penalties for members with serious violations;  (10) Decide on changes of the exchange;  (11) Powers to take temporary disposal measures when circumstances under Article 44 arise;  (12) Powers to take emergency measures under abnormal circumstances;  (13) Review and approve implementing rules and measures formulated pursuant to the trading rules;  (14) Review and approve the use and administration of the risk reserve fund;  (15) Review and approve development plans and annual work plans proposed by the general manager;  (16) Other powers provided in the articles of association and conferred by the members’ general assembly.  The powers set forth in items (8) and (9) of the preceding paragraph may be delegated by the council to specialized committees.**Article 25**  The council shall be composed of 9 to 15 members, among whom non-member directors shall account for no less than one-third and no more than one-half of the total number of council members.  Each director shall serve a term of three years, and no director may serve more than two consecutive terms.  Member directors shall be elected by the members’ general assembly from candidates proposed by the council or jointly by one-fifth or more of the members. Non-member directors shall be appointed by the CSRC.**Article 26**  The council shall have one chair and one to two vice-chairs. The chair and vice-chairs shall be nominated by the CSRC and elected by the council.  The chair shall not concurrently serve as the general manager.**Article 27**  The chair shall exercise the following powers:  (1) Preside over the members’ general assembly;  (2) Preside over meetings of the council;  (3) Preside over the day-to-day work of the council;  (4) Organize and coordinate the work of specialized committees;  (5) Inspect the implementation of council resolutions and report to the council.  The vice-chairs shall assist the chair. Where the chair is temporarily unable to perform duties, a vice-chair designated by the chair or another director shall act in the chair’s stead.**Article 28**  Council meetings shall be held once every six months. All directors shall be notified at least 10 days prior to each meeting.  An extraordinary council meeting shall be convened under any of the following circumstances:  (1) Upon proposal by the CSRC;  (2) Where the exchange declares the occurrence of an abnormal situation or circumstances under Article 44 arise;  (3) Upon a joint proposal by more than one-third of the directors.  For extraordinary meetings, the method and time limits for notice may be otherwise specified.**Article 29**  A council meeting shall be valid only if more than two-thirds of the directors are present; resolutions shall be adopted by a vote of more than one-half of all directors.  Within three days after the end of the meeting, the council shall file the meeting resolutions and other meeting documents with the CSRC for the record.**Article 30**  Council meetings shall be attended by directors in person. A director who is unable to attend shall, in writing, entrust another director to attend on his or her behalf; the letter of authorization shall specify the scope of authorization. Each director may accept authorization from only one other director.  Minutes shall be kept for voting matters at council meetings and signed by the directors present and by the recorder.**Article 31**  The council of a futures exchange may establish specialized committees such as supervision, trading, delivery, membership qualification review, mediation, and finance committees.  The specific duties of specialized committees shall be determined by the council, and the committees shall be responsible to the council.**Article 32**  A futures exchange shall have one general manager and several deputy general managers. The general manager and deputy general managers shall be appointed or removed by the CSRC. The term of office of the general manager shall be three years and may not exceed two consecutive terms.  The general manager is the legal representative of the futures exchange and shall serve ex officio as a director.**Article 33**  The general manager shall exercise the following powers:  (1) Organize the implementation of the systems and resolutions adopted by the members’ general assembly and the council;  (2) Preside over the day-to-day operations of the exchange;  (3) Draft implementing rules and measures pursuant to the articles of association and trading rules;  (4) Draft and implement approved development plans and annual work plans of the exchange;  (5) Draft the budgets and final accounts of the exchange;  (6) Draft plans for merger, division, dissolution, and liquidation of the exchange;  (7) Draft plans for changes to the exchange;  (8) Decide on the organizational set-up of the exchange and hire and dismiss staff;  (9) Decide on staff remuneration and rewards and penalties;  (10) Other powers provided in the articles of association or conferred by the council.  Where the general manager is temporarily unable to perform duties, a deputy general manager designated by the general manager shall act in the general manager’s stead.**Article 34**  The chair of the council, the general manager, and the deputy general managers shall not concurrently hold positions as State civil servants.**Article 35**  The appointment and removal of middle-level managers of a futures exchange shall be filed with the CSRC for the record.**Article 36**  None of the following persons may serve as senior management personnel, financial and accounting personnel, or directors of a futures exchange:  (1) Persons falling under any of the circumstances listed in Article 10 of the *Interim Regulations on the Administration of Futures Trading*;  (2) Practitioners of a futures brokerage company or other financial institution who were dismissed for illegal acts, for a period of five years from the date of dismissal;  (3) State civil servants who were expelled from public office, for a period of five years from the date of expulsion;  (4) Persons whom the CSRC has announced to be prohibited from entry into the securities and futures markets.**Article 37**  Where the general manager or deputy general managers of a futures exchange, during their term of office, commit acts that violate relevant state laws, regulations, rules, policies, or the exchange’s articles of association or business rules, or for other reasons are not suitable to continue serving, the CSRC shall remove them from office in accordance with procedures.---# Chapter IV  Administration of Members**Article 38**  Members of a futures exchange shall be corporate legal persons registered within the territory of the People’s Republic of China and shall have good credit standing.  Members of a futures exchange are divided into futures brokerage company members and non–futures brokerage company members.**Article 39**  Acquisition of membership shall be subject to the approval of the futures exchange, and the membership fee shall be paid.**Article 40**  Transfer or succession of membership shall be subject to the approval of the futures exchange and the completion of relevant formalities.**Article 41**  A futures exchange shall formulate membership administration measures.  Such measures shall include:  (1) Conditions and procedures for acquiring membership;  (2) Conditions and procedures for changing membership;  (3) Supervision and administration of members;  (4) Handling of members’ violations and defaults;  (5) Other matters that need to be provided for in the membership administration measures.**Article 42**  Members shall enjoy the following rights:  (1) Participate in the members’ general assembly and exercise rights to elect, to be elected, and to vote;  (2) Exercise the right to appeal in accordance with the articles of association and trading rules of the exchange;  (3) Engage in futures trading on the exchange;  (4) Use the trading facilities provided by the exchange and obtain information and services related to futures trading;  (5) Transfer membership as prescribed;  (6) Jointly propose the convening of an extraordinary members’ meeting;  (7) Other rights provided in the articles of association of the exchange.**Article 43**  Members shall perform the following obligations:  (1) Comply with relevant state laws, regulations, rules, and policies;  (2) Comply with the articles of association, business rules, and relevant decisions of the exchange;  (3) Pay various fees as prescribed;  (4) Implement resolutions of the members’ general assembly and the council;  (5) Accept the business supervision of the exchange;  (6) Other obligations provided in the articles of association of the exchange.**Article 44**  Where there is reason to believe that a member or client has violated the business rules of the exchange and is causing or is likely to cause a significant impact on the market, the exchange may, in order to prevent further expansion of the consequences of the violation, take the following temporary disposal measures against such member or client:  (1) Restrict deposits;  (2) Restrict withdrawals;  (3) Restrict the opening of new positions;  (4) Raise margin ratios;  (5) Order position reduction within a specified time;  (6) Enforce forced liquidation.  The temporary disposal measures set forth in items (1), (2), and (3) of the preceding paragraph may be decided by the general manager of the exchange; other temporary disposal measures shall be decided by the council and filed with the CSRC for the record.  When taking temporary disposal measures, the exchange shall notify the member or client in the manner prescribed by the exchange’s business rules and specify the grounds for such measures.**Article 45**  Members of a futures exchange shall use their trading seats in accordance with relevant provisions.  It is strictly prohibited for members to lease, contract out, or otherwise permit other institutions or individuals to use all or part of their seats.**Article 46**  Members of a futures exchange shall accept the supervision and administration of the exchange.  When exercising supervisory powers, the exchange may, within the scope of authority and procedures provided in its articles of association, trading rules, and implementing details, conduct investigations and collect evidence from members, and members shall cooperate.---# Chapter V  Basic Business Rules**Article 47**  Futures trading must be conducted through centralized bidding on the futures exchange, and over-the-counter transactions not matched through centralized bidding on the exchange are prohibited.  Futures trading shall follow the principles of price priority and time priority in matching trades.**Article 48**  The transaction fees collected by the exchange through its members shall not exceed the standards specified in the futures contracts.**Article 49**  Margin collected by the exchange from its members shall be used to secure the performance of futures contracts.  Margin is owned by the members. The exchange shall open a dedicated settlement account with its designated clearing bank to hold members’ margin funds on a segregated basis and shall not misappropriate such funds.**Article 50**  A futures exchange may stipulate the minimum balance of members’ margin in the dedicated settlement account. Where a member’s margin balance falls below the minimum stipulated by the exchange, the exchange shall notify the member in the manner and within the time limit prescribed by the business rules to provide additional margin, and the member shall make timely replenishment; if the member fails to do so within the time limit, the exchange shall enforce forced liquidation until the remaining margin reaches the prescribed minimum balance.  Where an instruction for forced liquidation cannot be executed due to market reasons, the exchange shall not bear liability.  Fees and losses arising from forced liquidation shall be borne by the member.**Article 51**  A futures exchange may stipulate the margin ratios to be collected from members, which shall not be lower than the ratios prescribed by the CSRC.  Margin shall be paid in monetary funds. Offsetting margin with negotiable treasury bonds eligible for listing and circulation or with standard warehouse receipts shall comply with relevant provisions.  Bank guarantees, bank deposit certificates, and custodial vouchers for treasury bonds shall not be used to offset margin.**Article 52**  A futures exchange shall allocate 20% of its fee income to a risk reserve fund. Where the balance of the risk reserve fund reaches ten times the registered capital of the exchange, further allocations may cease upon approval by the CSRC.  The CSRC may, in light of the exchange’s business scale, development plan, and potential risks, decide whether to continue allocating to the risk reserve fund.  The risk reserve fund shall be accounted for separately and held in a dedicated account.**Article 53**  Settlement of futures trading shall be organized in a unified manner by the exchange, and a daily mark-to-market settlement system shall be implemented.  After the market closes each day, the exchange shall promptly notify members of the trading and settlement results. Members shall confirm the results within the prescribed time.**Article 54**  A futures exchange shall implement a client trading code system. Futures brokerage company members and clients must comply with the “one account, one code” requirement and shall not mix codes in trading.**Article 55**  A futures exchange shall implement a hedging position approval system.  Where a non–futures brokerage company member or a client applies for hedging positions, it/he shall submit materials such as scope of business, operating performance, and spot purchase-and-sale contracts to the exchange; the exchange shall determine the hedging positions upon review.  Where a client applies for hedging positions, the futures brokerage company member shall review the submitted materials and then submit them to the exchange for review.  A non–futures brokerage company member or client shall submit materials truthfully when applying for hedging positions. Where such member or client intentionally conceals facts and fails to perform the obligation of truthful submission, or negligently fails to perform such obligation, the exchange shall have the right to cancel its hedging positions, and the futures brokerage company shall have the right to terminate the brokerage contract with such client; losses thereby caused shall be borne by the client.  Hedging positions shall not be reused and may only be closed out within the prescribed period or settled by physical delivery.**Article 56**  A futures exchange shall implement a speculative position limit system, formulating separate maximum position limits for speculative positions held by members and clients in non-delivery months and in delivery months.  Where a member or client holds positions exceeding the maximum position limit, the exchange shall have the right to enforce forced liquidation for the excess portion; fees and losses arising from forced liquidation shall be borne by the member, and profits shall be handled in accordance with relevant state provisions.  Positions held by the same client at different futures brokerage company members shall be aggregated for calculation.**Article 57**  A futures exchange shall implement a large-position reporting system. When a member’s or client’s positions reach 80% of the maximum speculative position limit, the non–futures brokerage company member or the futures brokerage company on behalf of the client shall report relevant information to the exchange.  The exchange may, in light of market risk conditions, adjust the position reporting standards.  Positions held by the same client at different futures brokerage company members shall be aggregated for calculation.**Article 58**  When futures prices hit the up-limit or down-limit for several consecutive sessions in the same direction, the exchange may adopt measures such as adjusting the limit range, raising trading margin ratios, and reducing positions according to certain principles to defuse risks.  The exchange shall adopt the measures under the preceding paragraph in accordance with the conditions and procedures prescribed in its trading rules and implementing details.**Article 59**  During futures trading, if any of the following circumstances occurs, the exchange may declare the occurrence of an abnormal situation and take emergency measures to defuse risks:  (1) Trading cannot proceed normally due to force majeure such as earthquake, flood, or fire, or for reasons not attributable to the exchange such as computer system failures;  (2) A member encounters a clearing or delivery crisis;  (3) The circumstance described in Article 58 of these Measures occurs, and risks remain unresolved after corresponding measures have been taken;  (4) Other circumstances specified in the exchange’s business rules.  Where an abnormal situation under item (1) of the preceding paragraph occurs, the general manager of the exchange may take emergency measures such as delayed market opening or suspension of trading; where abnormal situations under items (2), (3), or (4) occur, the council may decide to take emergency measures such as delayed market opening, suspension of trading, adjusting the limit range, raising trading margin ratios, ordering position reduction within a specified time, enforcing forced liquidation, or restricting withdrawals.  When taking emergency measures, the exchange shall notify members in the manner prescribed by its business rules.**Article 60**  Before declaring the occurrence of an abnormal situation and deciding to take emergency measures, the exchange must report to the CSRC.  Under any of the following circumstances, the CSRC has the authority to veto:  (1) The proposed emergency measures contravene relevant state laws, regulations, rules, policies, or the exchange’s articles of association, trading rules, and relevant implementing details;  (2) The proposed emergency measures have not been adopted through the prescribed procedures;  (3) The proposed emergency measures are not conducive to defusing futures market risks.**Article 61**  Where the exchange declares the occurrence of an abnormal situation and decides to suspend trading, the suspension shall not exceed three trading days, unless an extension is approved by the CSRC.**Article 62**  A futures exchange shall publish real-time quotations in an appropriate manner.  Real-time quotations shall include the following:  (1) Names of futures products and contract months;  (2) Opening price, highest price, lowest price, latest price, bid price, bid size, ask price, ask size, closing price, settlement price, and the settlement price of the previous trading day;  (3) Price change of the latest price compared with the settlement price of the previous trading day;  (4) Trading volume and open interest calculated on a double-counted basis;  (5) Other matters required by the CSRC to be disclosed.**Article 63**  A futures exchange shall, on a daily basis and in an appropriate manner, publish the following market quotations:  (1) Names of futures products and contract months;  (2) Opening price, highest price, lowest price, closing price, settlement price of the previous trading day, and settlement price of the day;  (3) Price change of the closing price compared with the settlement price of the previous trading day;  (4) Breakdown and totals of trading volume and open interest calculated on a double-counted basis;  (5) Other matters required by the CSRC to be published.**Article 64**  After the market closes each day, the exchange shall, for actively traded contracts, publish by contract month and by long/short side the list of the top twenty members by open interest and the corresponding positions, and the list of the top twenty members by trading volume and the corresponding volumes.  After the market closes on each Friday, the exchange shall publish, for each product, the number of standard warehouse receipts, weekly changes in the number of standard warehouse receipts, and the storage capacity available for futures delivery.  The exchange shall publish the results of delivery matching after delivery matching is completed, and shall publish the volume of physical deliveries after the final delivery day.**Article 65**  A futures exchange shall compile weekly, monthly, and annual reports on trading conditions within its market and publish them in a timely manner.**Article 66**  Where a member fails to perform a futures contract, the exchange shall successively assume performance on its behalf in the following order:  (1) Utilize the defaulting member’s margin;  (2) Utilize the exchange’s risk reserve fund;  (3) Utilize the exchange’s own funds.  Where the exchange has performed on behalf of a member by the methods set forth in items (2) and (3) of the preceding paragraph, it shall, in accordance with law, seek recourse against that member.**Article 67**  Delivery in futures trading shall be organized in a unified manner by the exchange.  The exchange shall not restrict the total amount of physical delivery.**Article 68**  Designated delivery warehouses shall be designated by the exchange. The exchange shall enter into agreements with designated delivery warehouses to specify the rights and obligations of both parties, and shall supervise and administer the business of designated delivery warehouses related to futures delivery.  Designated delivery warehouses shall ensure the quantity and quality of the deliverable goods represented by standard warehouse receipts.**Article 69**  Standard warehouse receipts shall be issued by designated delivery warehouses and shall take effect upon registration with the exchange.  Standard warehouse receipts may be transferred, and both parties to the transfer must register the transfer with the exchange. A transfer of a standard warehouse receipt that is not registered shall be invalid.**Article 70**  A futures exchange shall ensure the completeness and safety of records relating to futures trading, settlement, and delivery.  The retention period for the foregoing records shall be not less than twenty years.---# Chapter VI  Supervision and Administration**Article 71**  A futures exchange shall obtain the approval of the CSRC for the following matters:  (1) Formulating or amending its articles of association and trading rules;  (2) Listing, suspending, canceling, or resuming trading of futures products;  (3) Listing, amending, or terminating futures contracts;  (4) Conducting networked trading among futures exchanges;  (5) Other matters as prescribed by the CSRC.  Where a futures exchange formulates or amends business rules other than the articles of association and trading rules, it shall file them with the CSRC for the record.**Article 72**  Upon the departure of the general manager, the council of the exchange shall engage an intermediary institution qualified to conduct securities- and futures-related business to carry out an exit audit. The intermediary engaged and the audit report shall be filed with the CSRC for the record.  Where the CSRC deems it necessary, it may designate an intermediary institution or dispatch personnel to participate in the exit audit.**Article 73**  The chair of the council, the general manager, and the deputy general managers of a futures exchange shall not concurrently hold positions in any profit-making organization.  Non-member directors and staff of a futures exchange shall not, in any form, concurrently hold positions in member entities of the exchange or other profit-making entities related to futures trading.**Article 74**  Staff of a futures exchange shall not seek benefits from members or clients of the exchange, and shall not, directly or indirectly, engage in futures trading.**Article 75**  The income of a futures exchange shall be administered and used in accordance with relevant provisions and shall be used on a priority basis to ensure the normal operation and improvement of the trading venues and facilities of the exchange.**Article 76**  A futures exchange shall fulfill the following reporting obligations to the CSRC:  (1) Within three months after the end of each year, submit financial accounting reports audited by an accounting firm recognized by the CSRC;  (2) Within 15 days after the end of each quarter and within 30 days after the end of each year, submit quarterly and annual work reports on its operations and on the implementation of relevant laws, regulations, rules, and policies;  (3) Other reporting matters as required by the CSRC.**Article 77**  Upon the occurrence of major events, a futures exchange shall report to the CSRC in a timely manner.  “Major events,” as referred to in the preceding paragraph, include:  (1) Discovery that market participants or staff of the exchange are engaged in, or may be engaged in, serious violations of relevant state laws, regulations, rules, or policies;  (2) Litigation involving the exchange or its staff in an amount exceeding RMB 500,000;  (3) Other matters specified by the CSRC.**Article 78**  Where members of a futures exchange violate the business rules of the exchange, the exchange shall handle such violations in a timely manner and report to the CSRC.**Article 79**  The CSRC may, in light of market conditions, adjust trading margin ratios and transaction fee ratios charged by futures exchanges, and suspend, resume, or cancel trading of a particular futures product.**Article 80**  When abnormal conditions arise in the futures market, the CSRC may decide to take emergency measures such as delayed market opening, suspension of trading, adjusting the limit range, raising trading margin ratios, ordering position reduction within a specified time, enforcing forced liquidation, or restricting withdrawals.**Article 81**  The CSRC may station inspectors at a futures exchange. Inspectors shall perform their duties in accordance with relevant provisions of the CSRC.  A futures exchange shall cooperate with inspectors in the performance of their duties.**Article 82**  A futures exchange shall pay futures market regulatory fees to the CSRC in a timely manner in accordance with relevant state provisions.---# Chapter VII  Penalties**Article 83**  Where a futures brokerage company member leases, contracts out, or otherwise permits other institutions or individuals to use all or part of its seat, punishment shall be imposed in accordance with Article 59 of the *Interim Regulations on the Administration of Futures Trading*.  Where a non–futures brokerage company member commits the conduct described in the preceding paragraph, it shall be ordered to make corrections and its illegal gains shall be confiscated; where the circumstances are serious, the exchange shall be ordered to cancel its membership.**Article 84**  Other violations of these Measures shall be punished in accordance with the *Interim Regulations on the Administration of Futures Trading*.**Article 85**  Where violations of these Measures cause damage to others, civil liability shall be borne in accordance with law.---# Chapter VIII  Supplementary Provisions**Article 86**  “Business rules,” as used in these Measures, refers to the trading rules of a futures exchange and their implementing details.**Article 87**  Articles of association, trading rules, and implementing details of futures exchanges that became effective prior to the implementation of these Measures shall remain in force, but must be brought into conformity with these Measures within the time limit prescribed by the CSRC.**Article 88**  Where provisions previously issued by the CSRC prior to the implementation of these Measures are inconsistent with these Measures, these Measures shall prevail.**Article 89**  These Measures shall be interpreted by the CSRC.**Article 90**  These Measures shall come into force on September 1, 1999.  ① This regulation was repealed by the *Measures for the Administration of Futures Exchanges (2002)* (CSRC Order No. 6, May 17, 2002).  ② This regulation was repealed by the *Notice of the China Securities Regulatory Commission on Repealing Certain Securities and Futures Rules (Batch IV)* (CSRC Legal Affairs [2003] No. 15, November 20, 2003).
text_chn: 期货交易所管理办法证监期货字〔1999〕43号第一章总则1第二章设立、变更与终止1第三章组织机构4第四章对会员的管理8第五章基本业务规则10第六章监督与管理14第七章罚则16第八章附则16第一章总则第一条为了加强对期货交易所的管理，明确期货交易所的职权和责任，防范市场风险，维护期货市场的正常秩序，根据《期货交易管理暂行条例》，制定本办法。第二条本办法适用于在中华人民共和国境内设立的期货交易所。第三条期货交易所指依照《期货交易管理暂行条例》和本办法规定条件设立的，不以营利为目的，履行《期货交易管理暂行条例》和本办法规定的职能，按照其章程实行自律性管理的法人。第四条中国证券监督管理委员会（以下简称“中国证监会”）依法对期货交易所实行集中统一的监督管理。第二章设立、变更与终止第五条设立期货交易所，由中国证监会审批。未经批准，任何单位或者个人不得设立或者变相设立期货交易所。期货交易所的名称，应当标明商品交易所或者期货交易所字样。其他任何单位或者个人不得使用商品交易所、期货交易所或者近似的名称。第六条期货交易所的注册资本划分为均等份额的会员资格费，由会员出资认缴。期货交易所的权益由会员共同享有，在其存续期间，不得将其积累分配给会员。第七条期货交易所应当履行下列职能：（一）提供期货交易的场所、设施及相关服务；（二）制定并实施期货交易所的业务规则；（三）设计期货合约、安排期货合约上市；1（四）组织、监督期货交易、结算和交割；（五）制定并实施风险管理制度，控制市场风险；（六）保证期货合约的履行；（七）发布市场信息；（八）监管会员期货业务，检查会员违法、违规行为；（九）监管指定交割仓库的期货业务；（十）中国证监会规定的其他职能。第八条期货交易所不得从事信托投资、股票交易、非自用不动产投资等与其职能无关的业务；除为期货合约的履行提供履约保证外，不得为其他单位或者个人提供担保；不得发布对期货价格进行预测的文字和资料。禁止期货交易所直接或者间接参与期货交易。第九条申请设立期货交易所，应当向中国证监会提交下列文件和材料：（一）申请书；（二）章程和交易规则草案；（三）期货交易所的经营计划；（四）拟加入本交易所的会员名单；（五）理事会成员候选人名单及简历；（六）场地、设备、资金证明文件及情况说明；（七）拟任用高级管理人员的名单及其简历；（八）中国证监会要求提交的其他文件、材料。第十条期货交易所章程应当载明下列事项：（一）设立目的和职能；（二）名称、住所和营业场所；（三）注册资本及会员的出资额；（四）营业期限；（五）会员资格的取得；（六）会员的权利和义务；（七）组织机构的设置、职权和议事规则；（八）管理人员的产生、任免及其职责；（九）基本业务规则；（十）风险准备金管理制度；（十一）财务会计、内部审计制度；（十二）变更、终止的条件、程序及清算办法；（十三）章程修改程序；（十四）需要在章程中规定的其他事项。2第十一条期货交易所交易规则应当载明下列事项：（一）交易地点和时间；（二）上市品种和期货合约；（三）期货合约交易的暂停、恢复与取消程序；（四）交易大厅的管理制度；（五）经纪和自营业务规则；（六）风险控制制度和交易异常情况的处理程序；（七）期货结算和交割制度；（八）保证金的管理和使用制度；（九）期货交易信息的发布办法；（十）违规、违约行为及其处理办法；（十一）交易纠纷的处理方式；（十二）需要在交易规则中载明的其他事项。第十二条期货交易所的合并、分立，由中国证监会审核批准。期货交易所合并的，可以采取吸收合并和新设合并两种方式；合并前各方的债权、债务，由合并后存续或者新设的期货交易所承继。期货交易所分立的，其债权、债务由分立后的期货交易所承继。第十三条未经中国证监会批准，期货交易所不得设立分所或者其他任何期货交易场所。第十四条期货交易所有下列变更事项之一的，应当报中国证监会批准：（一）变更名称；（二）变更住所或者营业场所；（三）中国证监会规定的其他变更事项。第十五条有下列情形之一的，期货交易所终止：（一）章程规定的营业期限届满，会员大会决定不再延续；（二）会员大会决定解散；（三）因合并或者分立而解散；（四）中国证监会决定关闭。3期货交易所因前款第（一）、（二）、（三）项解散，由中国证监会批准。期货交易所终止，应当成立清算组，进行清算。清算组制定的清算方案，应当报中国证监会批准。第十六条期货交易所终止的，由中国证监会予以公告。期货交易所会员自公告之日起９０日内，应当结清期货交易业务。第三章组织机构第十七条期货交易所设会员大会和理事会。第十八条会员大会是期货交易所的权力机构，由全体会员组成。会员大会行使下列职权：（一）通过期货交易所章程和交易规则及其修改草案；（二）选举和罢免会员理事；（三）审议批准理事会、总经理的工作报告；（四）审议批准期货交易所的财务预算方案、决算报告；（五）审议期货交易所风险准备金使用情况；（六）决定增加或者减少期货交易所注册资本；（七）决定期货交易所的合并、分立、解散和清算事项；（八）决定期货交易所理事会提交的其他重大事项；（九）期货交易所章程规定的其他职权。第十九条会员大会由理事会召集，一般情况下每年召开一次。有下列情形之一的，应当召开临时会员大会：（一）会员理事不足本办法规定的最低数目或者期货交易所章程所定数目的三分之二时；（二）三分之一以上会员联名提议时；（三）理事会认为必要时。第二十条会员大会由理事长主持。理事长因特殊原因不能履行职权时，由理事长指定的副理事长或者其4他理事主持。召开会员大会，应当将会议审议的事项于会议召开３０日以前通过各会员。临时会员大会不得对通知中未列明的事项作出决议。第二十一条会员大会必须有三分之二以上会员出席，每一会员享有一票表决权。会员大会决议必须经全体会员二分之一以上通过。会员大会对期货交易所合并、分立、解散和清算、增加或者减少期货交易所注册资本作出决议，必须经全体会员三分之二以上通过。第二十二条会员参加会员大会，应当由其法定代表人出席。法定代表人因故不能出席会员大会的，会员可以委托代理人出席会员大会，代理人应当向期货交易所提交会员授权委托书，并在授权范围内行使表决权。第二十三条会员大会应当对表决事项制作会议纪要，由出席会议的理事签名。会员大会结束后３日内，期货交易所应当将大会全部文件报中国证监会备案。第二十四条理事会是会员大会的常设机构，对会员大会负责。理事会行使下列职权：（一）召集会员大会，并向会员大会报告工作；（二）监督会员大会决议和理事会决议的实施；（三）监督总经理履行职务行为；（四）拟定期货交易所章程、交易规则及其修改草案，提交会员大会通过；（五）审议总经理提出的财务预算方案、决算报告，提交会员大会通过；（六）审议期货交易所合并、分立、解散和清算的方案，提交会员大会通过；（七）决定专门委员会的设置；（八）决定会员的接纳；（九）决定对严重违规会员的处罚；（十）决定期货交易所的变更事项；（十一）出现本办法第四十四条的情况时采取临时处置措施的权力；（十二）异常情况下采取紧急措施的权力；（十三）审定根据交易规则制定的细则和办法；（十四）审定风险准备金的使用和管理办法；（十五）审定总经理提出的期货交易所发展规划和年度工作计划；（十六）期货交易所章程规定和会员大会授予的其他职权。5前款第（八）、（九）项的职权，理事会可授予专门委员会行使。第二十五条理事会由９至１５人组成，其中非会员理事不少于理事会成员总数的三分之一，不超过理事会成员总数的二分之一。理事每届任期３年。理事连续任职不得超过两届。会员理事由理事会或者五分之一以上会员联名提议，由会员大会差额选举产生。非会员理事由中国证监会委派。第二十六条理事会设理事长１人、副理事长１至２人。理事长、副理事长由中国证监会提名，理事会选举产生。理事长不得兼任总经理。第二十七条理事长行使下列职权：（一）主持会员大会；（二）主持理事会会议；（三）主持理事会的日常工作；（四）组织协调专门委员会的工作；（五）检查理事会决议的实施情况并向理事会报告。副理事长协助理事长工作，理事长因故临时不能履行职权时，由理事长指定的副理事长或者理事代其履行职权。第二十八条理事会会议每半年召开１次。每次会议应当于会议召开１０日前通知全体理事。有下列情形之一的，应当召开理事会临时会议：（一）中国证监会提议；（二）交易所宣布进入异常情况或者出现本办法第四十四条的情况；（三）三分之一以上理事联名提议。理事会召开临时会议，可以另定召集理事会临时会议的通知方式和通知时限。第二十九条理事会会议须有三分之二以上理事出席，其决议须经全体理事二分之一以上表决通过。6理事会会议结束后３日内，理事会应当将会议决议及其他会议文件报中国证监会备案。第三十条理事会会议，应当由理事本人出席。理事因故不能出席的，应当以书面形式委托其他理事代为出席；委托书中应载明授权范围。每位理事只能接受一位理事的授权。理事会应当对会议表决事项作成会议记录，由出席会议的理事和记录员在会议记录上签名。第三十一条期货交易所理事会可以设立监察、交易、交割、会员资格审查、调解、财务等专门委员会。专门委员会的具体职责由理事会确定，专门委员会对理事会负责。第三十二条期货交易所设总经理１人，副总经理若干人。总经理、副总经理由中国证监会任免。总经理每届任期３年，连任不得超过两届。总经理是期货交易所的法定代表人，总经理是当然理事。第三十三条总经理行使下列职权：（一）组织实施会员大会、理事会通过的制度和决议；（二）主持期货交易所的日常工作；（三）根据章程和交易规则拟定有关细则和办法；（四）拟定并实施经批准的期货交易所发展规划、年度工作计划；（五）拟定期货交易所财务预算方案、决算报告；（六）拟定期货交易所合并、分立、解散和清算的方案；（七）拟定期货交易所变更方案；（八）决定期货交易所机构设置方案，聘任和解聘工作人员；（九）决定期货交易所员工的工资和奖惩；（十）期货交易所章程规定的或者理事会授予的其他职权。总经理因故临时不能履行职责时，由总经理指定的副总经理代其履行职责。第三十四条理事长、总经理、副总经理不得由国家公务员兼任。第三十五条7期货交易所中层管理人员的任免报中国证监会备案。第三十六条有下列情形之一的，不得担任期货交易所高级管理人员、财务会计人员和理事：（一）有《期货交易管理暂行条例》第十条所列情形之一的；（二）因违法行为被解除职务的期货经纪公司或者其他金融机构的从业人员，自被解除职务之日起未逾５年的；（三）被开除的国家公务员，自被开除之日起未逾５年的；（四）被中国证监会宣布为证券、期货市场禁止进入者的。第三十七条期货交易所总经理、副总经理在任期内有违反国家有关法律、法规、规章、政策和期货交易所章程、业务规则的行为，或者由于其他原因，不适宜继续担任其职务时，由中国证监会按程序解除其职务。第四章对会员的管理第三十八条期货交易所会员应当是在中华人民共和国境内注册登记的企业法人，并具有良好的资信。期货交易所会员分为期货经纪公司会员和非期货经纪公司会员。第三十九条取得会员资格，应当经期货交易所批准，并缴纳会员资格费。第四十条转让或者承继会员资格的，应当经期货交易所批准，并履行相关手续。第四十一条期货交易所应当制定会员管理办法。会员管理办法内容包括：（一）会员资格的取得条件和程序；（二）会员资格的变更条件和程序；（三）对会员的监督管理；（四）会员违规、违约行为的处理；（五）其他需要在会员管理办法中规定的事项。8第四十二条会员享有下列权利：（一）参加会员大会，行使选举权、被选举权和表决权；（二）按照期货交易所章程和交易规则行使申诉权；（三）在期货交易所内进行期货交易；（四）使用期货交易所提供的交易设施，获得有关期货交易的信息和服务；（五）按规定转让会员资格；（六）联名提议召开临时会员大会；（七）期货交易所章程规定的其他权利。第四十三条会员应当履行下列义务：（一）遵守国家有关法律、法规、规章和政策；（二）遵守期货交易所的章程、业务规则及有关决定；（三）按规定交纳各种费用；（四）执行会员大会、理事会的决议；（五）接受期货交易所业务监管；（六）期货交易所章程规定的其他义务。第四十四条有根据认为会员或者客户违反期货交易所业务规则并且对市场正在产生或者将产生重大影响，为防止违规行为后果进一步扩大，期货交易所可以对该会员或者客户采取下列临时处置措施：（一）限制入金；（二）限制出金；（三）限制开新仓；（四）提高保证金比例；（五）限期平仓；（六）强行平仓。前款第（一）、（二）、（三）项临时处置措施可以由期货交易所总经理决定，其他临时处置措施由期货交易所理事会决定，并报中国证监会备案。期货交易所对会员或者客户采取临时处置措施，应当按照期货交易所出现业务规则规定的方式通知会员或者客户，并列明采取临时处置措施的根据。第四十五条期货交易所会员应当按照有关规定使用其交易席位。严禁会员将席位全部或者部分以出租或者承包等形式交由其他机构和个人使用。9第四十六条期货交易所会员应当接受期货交易所监督管理。期货交易所行使监管职权时，可以按照期货交易所章程和交易规则及其细则规定的权限和程序对会员进行调查取证，会员应当配合。第五章基本业务规则第四十七条期货交易必须通过期货交易所集中竞价进行，禁止不通过期货交易所集中竞价撮合的场外交易。期货交易实行价格优先、时间优先的撮合成交原则。第四十八条期货交易所通过会员代收的交易手续费不得高于期货合约规定的标准。第四十九条期货交易所向会员收取的保证金，用于担保期货合约的履行。保证金属会员所有。期货交易所应当在其指定的结算银行开立专用结算帐户，专户存储会员保证金，不得挪用。第五十条期货交易所可以规定专用结算帐户中会员保证金的最低余额。当会员保证金余额低于期货交易所规定的最低余额时，期货交易所应当按照期货交易所业务规则规定的方式和时间通知会员追加保证金，会员应当按时补足；逾期未补足的，期货交易所应当强行平仓，直至所余保证金达到规定的最低余额。由于市场原因强行平仓指令无法执行的，期货交易所不承担责任。强行平仓的有关费用和发生的损失由会员承担。第五十一条期货交易所可以规定向会员收取的保证金比例，但不得低于中国证监会规定的比例。保证金应当以货币资金缴纳。可上市流通国库券、标准仓单折抵保证金，应当符合有关规定。10不得使用银行保函、银行存单、国库券代保管凭证等折抵保证金。第五十二条期货交易所应当按照手续费收入的２０％的比例提取风险准备金，风险准备金余额达到期货交易所注册资本的１０倍时，经中国证监会批准后可不再提取。中国证监会可以根据期货交易所业务规模、发展计划以及潜在的风险决定是否继续提取风险准备金。风险准备金必须单独核算，专户存储。第五十三条期货交易的结算，由期货交易所统一组织进行，实行每日无负债结算制度。期货交易所应当在当日收市后及时将交易结算结果通知会员。会员应当在规定时间内确认交易结算结果。第五十四条期货交易所实行客户交易编码制度。期货经纪公司会员和客户必须遵守一户一码制度，不得混码交易。第五十五条期货交易所实行套期保值头寸审批制度。非期货经纪公司会员或者客户申请套期保值头寸的，应当向期货交易所提交经营范围和经营业绩资料、现货购销合同等，由期货交易所审核后确定其套期保值头寸。客户申请套期保值的，由期货经纪公司会员对其提交材料审核后报期货交易所审核。非期货经纪公司会员或者客户申请套期保值的，应当如实提交材料。非期货经纪公司会员或者客户故意隐瞒事实，不履行如实提交材料义务的，或者因过失未履行如实提交材料义务的，期货交易所有权取消其套期保值头寸，期货经纪公司有权解除与该客户的期货经纪合同，由此造成的损失由客户负责。套期保值头寸不得重复使用，只能在规定期限内平仓或者实物交割。第五十六条期货交易所实行投机头寸限仓制度，对会员和客户在非交割月份和交割月份持有的投机头寸，分别制定最大持仓限制标准。11对持仓量超过最大持仓限制标准的会员和客户，期货交易所有权对超额部分进行强行平仓，强行平仓的有关费用和损失由会员自行承担，盈利部分根据国家的有关规定处理。同一客户在不同期货经纪公司会员处的持仓合并计算。第五十七条期货交易所实行大户报告制度。当会员或者客户的持仓达到投机头寸最大持仓限制标准的百分之八十时，由非期货经纪公司会员、期货经纪公司代客户向期货交易所报告有关情况。期货交易所可以根据市场风险状况，调整持仓报告标准。同一客户在不同期货经纪公司会员处的持仓合并计算。第五十八条当期货价格出现同方向连续涨跌停板时，期货交易所可以采用调整涨跌停板幅度、提高交易保证金比例及按一定原则减仓等措施化解风险。期货交易所采取前款措施，应当按照期货交易所交易规则及其实施细则规定的条件和程序进行。第五十九条在期货交易过程中，如果出现以下情形，期货交易所可以宣布进入异常情况，采取紧急措施化解风险：（一）地震、水灾、火灾等不可抗力或者计算机系统故障等不可归责于期货交易所的原因导致交易无法正常进行；（二）会员出现结算、交割危机；（三）出现本办法第五十八条情况并采取相应措施后仍未化解风险；（四）期货交易所业务规则中规定的其他情况。出现前款第（一）项异常情况时，期货交易所总经理可以采取延迟开市、暂停交易的紧急措施；出现前款第（二）、（三）、（四）项异常情况时，理事会可以决定采取延迟开市、暂停交易、调整涨跌停板幅度、提高交易保证金比例、限期平仓、强行平仓、限制出金等紧急措施。期货交易所采取紧急措施，应当按照期货交易所业务规则规定的方式通知会员。第六十条期货交易所宣布进入异常情况并决定采取紧急措施前必须报告中国证监会。有下列情形之一的，中国证监会有权否决：（一）拟采取的紧急措施违背国家有关法规、规章、政策和期货交易所章程、交易规则及其相12关实施细则的；（二）拟采取的紧急措施未经规定程序产生的；（三）拟采取的紧急措施不利于化解期货市场风险的。第六十一条期货交易所宣布进入异常情况并决定暂停交易时，暂停交易的期限不得超过３个交易日，但经中国证监会批准延长的除外。第六十二条期货交易所应当以适当方式发布即时行情。即时行情内容应当包括下列事项：（一）期货交易品种的名称、合约月份；（二）开盘价、最高价、最低价、最新价、申买价、申买量、申卖价、申卖量、收盘价、结算价及前一交易日结算价；（三）最新价与前一交易日结算价比较后的涨跌情况；（四）按双边计算的成交量、持仓量；（五）中国证监会要求公布的其他事项。第六十三条期货交易所应当按日以适当方式发布下列市场行情：（一）期货交易品种的名称、合约月份；（二）开盘价、最高价、最低价、收盘价、前一交易日结算价及当日结算价；（三）收盘价与前一交易日结算价比较后的涨跌情况；（四）按双边计算的成交量、持仓量的分计及合计；（五）中国证监会要求发布的其他事项。第六十四条期货交易所每日闭市后，应当对交易活跃的合约分月份、分多空方式公布当日持仓量前二十名会员名单及对应持仓量、成交量前二十名会员名单及对应成交量。期货交易所每周五闭市后应当公布本周各品种标准仓单数量、一周标准仓单变动情况、可供期货交割使用仓库容量等情况。期货交易所应当在交割配对完成后公布交割配对结果，并在最后交割日后公布实物交割量。第六十五条期货交易所应当就其市场内的交易情况编制周报表、月报表和年报表，并及时公布。第六十六条13会员未能履行期货合约时，期货交易所应当按下列顺序代为承担履约责任：（一）动用违约会员的保证金；（二）动用期货交易所的风险准备金；（三）动用期货交易所自有资金。期货交易所以前款（二）、（三）项的办法代会员履约后，应当依法向该会员追偿。第六十七条期货交易的交割，由期货交易所统一组织进行。期货交易所不得限制实物交割总量。第六十八条指定交割仓库由期货交易所指定。期货交易所应当与指定交割仓库签订协议，明确双方的权利和义务，对指定交割仓库与期货交割有关的业务进行监督管理。指定交割仓库应当保证标准仓单所代表的交割商品的数量和质量。第六十九条标准仓单由指定交割仓库签发并经期货交易所注册后生效。标准仓单可以转让，转让双方须在期货交易所登记。未经登记，标准仓单的转让行为无效。第七十条期货交易所应当保证期货交易、结算、交割资料的完整和安全。期货交易所对上述资料的保存期限不少于２０年。第六章监督与管理第七十一条期货交易所有下列事项的，应当报中国证监会批准：（一）制定或者修改章程、交易规则；（二）上市、中止、取消或者恢复期货交易品种；（三）期货合约的上市、修改和终止；（四）期货交易所之间进行联网交易；（五）中国证监会规定的其他事项。14期货交易所制定或者修改除章程、交易规则以外的业务规则，应当报中国证监会备案。第七十二条期货交易所总经理离任时，期货交易所理事会应当聘请具有从事证券期货相关业务资格的中介机构进行离任审计。期货交易所聘请的中介机构和审计报告应当报中国证监会备案。中国证监会认为必要时，可以指定中介机构或者派员参加离任审计。第七十三条期货交易所的理事长、总经理、副总经理不得在任何营利性组织中兼职。期货交易所的非会员理事和工作人员不得以任何形式在期货交易所会员单位及其他与期货交易有关的营利性单位兼职。第七十四条期货交易所工作人员不得从期货交易所的会员、客户处谋取利益，不得直接或者间接从事期货交易。第七十五条期货交易所的收入，应当按照有关规定管理和使用，优先用于保证期货交易场所和设施的正常运行和改善。第七十六条期货交易所应当向中国证监会履行下列报告义务：（一）每一年度结束后３个月内提交经中国证监会认可的会计师事务所审计的财务会计报告；（二）每一季度结束后１５日内、每一年度结束后３０日内提交有关经营情况和有关法律、法规、规章、政策的执行情况的季度和年度工作报告；（三）中国证监会要求的其他报告事项。第七十七条遇有重大事项，期货交易所应当有时向中国证监会报告。前款所称重大事项包括：（一）发现期货市场参与者或者期货交易所工作人员存在或者可能存在严重违反国家有关法律、法规、规章、政策的行为；（二）期货交易所或者期货交易所工作人员涉及５０万元以上诉讼；（三）中国证监会规定的其他事项。15第七十八条期货交易所对其会员违反业务规则的行为，应当及时处理，并向中国证监会报告。第七十九条中国证监会可以根据市场情况调整期货交易所收取的交易保证金比例、交易手续费比例，暂停、恢复或者取消某一期货交易品种的交易。第八十条期货市场出现异常情况时，中国证监会可以决定采取延迟开市、暂停交易、调整涨跌停板幅度、提高交易保证金比例、限期平仓、强行平仓、限制出金等紧急措施。第八十一条中国证监会可以向期货交易所派驻督察员。督察员应当依照中国证监会的有关规定履行职责。督察员履行职责，期货交易所应当予以配合。第八十二条期货交易所应当按照国家有关规定及时向中国证监会交纳期货市场监管费。第七章罚则第八十三条期货经纪公司会员将席位全部或者部分以出租或者承包等形式交由其他机构和个人使用，依照《期货交易管理暂行条例》第五十九条处罚。非期货经纪公司会员有前款行为的，责令改正，没收违法所得；情节严重的，责令期货交易所取消其会员资格。第八十四条其他违反本办法规定的，根据《期货交易管理暂行条例》处罚。第八十五条违反本办法规定，给他人造成损害的，应当依法承担民事责任。第八章附则16第八十六条本办法所称业务规则指期货交易所交易规则及其实施细则。第八十七条本办法施行前已经生效的期货交易所章程、交易规则及其实施细则继续保留，但必须在中国证监会规定的期限内符合本办法的规定。第八十八条本办法施行前中国证监会发布的有关规定，凡与本办法相抵触的，以本办法为准。第八十九条本办法由中国证监会负责解释。第九十条本办法自１９９９年９月１日起施行。①本篇法规被《期货交易所管理办（2002）》（2002年5月17日中国证券监督管理委员会令第6号）废止②本篇法规被《中国证券监督管理委员会关于废止部分证券期货规章的通知（第四批）》（2003年11月20日证监法律字〔2003〕第15号）废止17

name_chn: 期货交易所管理办法（证监会令第6号）
text: # Measures for the Administration of Futures Exchanges  (CSRC Order No. 6)# Chapter I  General Provisions**Article 1**  For the purpose of strengthening the administration of futures exchanges, clarifying their powers and responsibilities, and maintaining the normal order of the futures market, these Measures are formulated in accordance with the *Interim Regulations on the Administration of Futures Trading*.**Article 2**  These Measures apply to futures exchanges established within the territory of the People’s Republic of China.**Article 3**  A “futures exchange,” as referred to in these Measures, means a legal person established in accordance with the conditions prescribed by the *Interim Regulations on the Administration of Futures Trading* and these Measures, which performs the functions stipulated in the *Interim Regulations on the Administration of Futures Trading* and these Measures, and implements self-regulation pursuant to its articles of association.  The registered capital of a futures exchange shall be divided into equal shares and subscribed by its members.**Article 4**  The China Securities Regulatory Commission (hereinafter, the “CSRC”) shall, in accordance with the law, exercise centralized and unified supervision and administration over futures exchanges.---# Chapter II  Establishment, Change, and Termination**Article 5**  The establishment of a futures exchange shall be subject to the approval of the CSRC. Without approval, no entity or individual may establish, or in a disguised form establish, a futures exchange.**Article 6**  An applicant for the establishment of a futures exchange shall submit the following documents and materials to the CSRC:  (1) An application letter;  (2) Draft articles of association and trading rules;  (3) The business plan of the futures exchange;  (4) A list of the prospective members of the exchange;  (5) A list and résumés of candidates for the council (board of directors);  (6) A list and résumés of proposed senior management personnel;  (7) Supporting documents and explanatory materials regarding premises, facilities, and funds;  (8) Other documents and materials as required by the CSRC.**Article 7**  A futures exchange established with CSRC approval shall bear in its name the wording “Commodity Exchange” or “Futures Exchange.” No other entity or individual may use the wording “Commodity Exchange,” “Futures Exchange,” or any similar name.**Article 8**  In addition to performing the functions prescribed by the *Interim Regulations on the Administration of Futures Trading*, a futures exchange shall perform the following functions:  (1) Formulate and implement the business rules of the futures exchange;  (2) Publish market information;  (3) Supervise members’ futures business and investigate members’ violations;  (4) Supervise the futures business of designated delivery warehouses;  (5) Supervise futures clearing business conducted by clearing banks in relation to the exchange.**Article 9**  The articles of association of a futures exchange shall specify the following matters:  (1) Purpose of establishment and functions;  (2) Name, domicile, and place of business;  (3) Registered capital and its composition;  (4) Term of operation;  (5) Membership qualifications and their administration;  (6) Rights and obligations of members;  (7) Disciplinary sanctions against members;  (8) Composition, powers, term of office, and rules of procedure of organizational bodies such as the members’ general assembly and the council;  (9) Selection, appointment and removal of management personnel, and their duties;  (10) Basic business rules;  (11) Risk reserve fund administration system;  (12) Financial accounting and internal audit systems;  (13) Conditions and procedures for change and termination, and methods of liquidation;  (14) Procedures for amending the articles of association;  (15) Other matters that need to be provided for in the articles of association.**Article 10**  The trading rules of a futures exchange shall specify the following matters:  (1) Systems for futures trading, delivery, and settlement;  (2) Rules for brokerage and proprietary trading;  (3) Risk control system and procedures for handling abnormal trading situations;  (4) Systems for the administration and use of margin;  (5) Rules for the creation, circulation, management, and cancellation of standard warehouse receipts;  (6) Methods for publishing futures trading information;  (7) Violations and defaults and measures for handling them;  (8) Methods for handling trading disputes;  (9) Other matters that need to be specified in the trading rules.**Article 11**  Mergers, divisions, or networked trading of futures exchanges shall be subject to CSRC approval.  A merger of futures exchanges may take the form of absorption or the establishment of a new exchange; the rights and obligations of the parties prior to the merger shall be succeeded to by the surviving or newly established futures exchange.  Where a futures exchange is divided, its rights and obligations shall be succeeded to by the futures exchanges resulting from the division.**Article 12**  Where a futures exchange encounters circumstances specified in Article 17 of the *Interim Regulations on the Administration of Futures Trading*, or undergoes any of the following changes, it shall obtain the approval of the CSRC:  (1) Change of name;  (2) Change of domicile or place of business.**Article 13**  Without the approval of the CSRC, a futures exchange shall not establish branches or any other futures trading venues.**Article 14**  Where a futures exchange encounters the circumstances specified in Article 20 of the *Interim Regulations on the Administration of Futures Trading*, or is terminated due to merger or division, the CSRC shall make a public announcement.  Upon termination of a futures exchange, a liquidation group shall be formed to conduct liquidation. The liquidation plan formulated by the liquidation group shall be submitted to the CSRC for approval.---# Chapter III  Organizational Structure**Article 15**  A futures exchange shall establish a members’ general assembly and a council.**Article 16**  The members’ general assembly is the authority of the futures exchange and is composed of all members.  The members’ general assembly shall exercise the following powers:  (1) Deliberate on and adopt the articles of association and trading rules of the futures exchange and draft amendments thereto;  (2) Elect and replace member directors;  (3) Deliberate on and approve the work reports of the council and the general manager;  (4) Deliberate on and approve the budgets and final accounts of the futures exchange;  (5) Deliberate on the use of the risk reserve fund of the futures exchange;  (6) Decide on increases or decreases of the registered capital of the futures exchange;  (7) Decide on matters relating to merger, division, dissolution, and liquidation of the futures exchange;  (8) Decide on other major matters submitted by the council;  (9) Other powers provided in the articles of association.**Article 17**  The members’ general assembly shall be convened by the council and, in general, shall be held once a year.  An extraordinary members’ meeting shall be convened under any of the following circumstances:  (1) The number of member directors falls below two-thirds of that specified in the articles of association;  (2) A joint proposal by more than one-third of the members;  (3) The council deems it necessary.**Article 18**  Meetings of the members’ general assembly shall be presided over by the chair of the council. Where the chair is, for special reasons, unable to perform duties, a vice-chair or another director designated by the chair shall preside. Members shall be notified of the matters to be deliberated no later than 10 days before the meeting is held. An extraordinary members’ meeting shall not adopt resolutions on matters not listed in the notice.**Article 19**  A meeting of the members’ general assembly shall be valid only if more than two-thirds of the members attend. Minutes shall be kept for voting matters and shall be signed by the directors attending the meeting.  Within 10 days after the end of the meeting, the futures exchange shall file all meeting documents with the CSRC for the record.**Article 20**  The council is the standing body of the members’ general assembly and is responsible to it.  The council shall exercise the following powers:  (1) Convene meetings of the members’ general assembly and report on its work thereto;  (2) Elect the chair and vice-chairs of the council;  (3) Adopt no-confidence motions against council members and submit them to the relevant authority for review and approval;  (4) Draft the articles of association, trading rules, and amendments thereto, and submit them to the members’ general assembly for adoption;  (5) Deliberate on the budgets and final accounts proposed by the general manager and submit them to the members’ general assembly for adoption;  (6) Deliberate on plans for merger, division, dissolution, and liquidation of the futures exchange and submit them to the members’ general assembly for adoption;  (7) Decide on the establishment of specialized committees;  (8) Decide on the admission of members;  (9) Decide on penalties for members’ violations;  (10) Decide on changes of the futures exchange;  (11) Review and approve implementing rules and measures formulated pursuant to the trading rules;  (12) Review and approve the administration and use of the risk reserve fund;  (13) Review and approve development plans and annual work plans proposed by the general manager;  (14) Supervise the implementation of resolutions of the members’ general assembly and the council by the general manager;  (15) Supervise compliance by senior management and other staff with relevant state laws, regulations, rules, policies, and the articles of association and business rules of the futures exchange;  (16) Organize the annual audit of the financial and accounting reports of the futures exchange and decide on the engagement and change of the accounting firm;  (17) Other powers provided in the articles of association and conferred by the members’ general assembly.  The council may delegate the foregoing powers to specialized committees or the general manager.**Article 21**  The council shall be composed of member directors and non-member directors. Member directors shall be elected by the members’ general assembly; non-member directors shall be appointed by the CSRC.**Article 22**  The council shall have one chair and one to two vice-chairs. The chair and vice-chairs shall be nominated by the CSRC and elected by the council. The chair shall not concurrently serve as the general manager.**Article 23**  The chair shall exercise the following powers:  (1) Preside over meetings of the members’ general assembly and the council, and the day-to-day work of the council;  (2) Organize and coordinate the work of specialized committees;  (3) Inspect the implementation of council resolutions and report to the council.  The vice-chairs shall assist the chair. Where the chair is temporarily unable to perform duties, a vice-chair or a director designated by the chair shall act in the chair’s stead.**Article 24**  Council meetings shall be held at least once every six months. All directors shall be notified at least 10 days prior to each meeting.  An extraordinary council meeting shall be convened under any of the following circumstances:  (1) Upon proposal by the CSRC;  (2) Upon a joint proposal by more than one-third of the directors;  (3) Under circumstances specified in the articles of association.  For extraordinary meetings, the method and time limits for notice may be otherwise specified.**Article 25**  A council meeting shall be valid only if more than two-thirds of the directors are present; resolutions shall be adopted by a vote of more than one-half of all directors.  Within 10 days after the end of the meeting, the council shall file the meeting resolutions and other meeting documents with the CSRC for the record.**Article 26**  Council meetings shall be attended by directors in person. A director who is unable to attend shall, in writing, entrust another director to attend on his or her behalf; the letter of authorization shall specify the scope of authorization. Each director may accept authorization from only one other director.  Minutes shall be kept for voting matters at council meetings and signed by the directors present and by the recorder.**Article 27**  The council may, as needed, establish specialized committees such as supervision, trading, delivery, membership qualification review, mediation, finance, and technology committees. Their functions shall be determined by the council, to which they shall be responsible.**Article 28**  A futures exchange shall have one general manager and several deputy general managers. The general manager and deputy general managers shall be appointed or removed by the CSRC. The term of office of the general manager shall be three years and may not exceed two consecutive terms.  The general manager is the legal representative of the futures exchange and shall serve ex officio as a director.**Article 29**  The general manager shall exercise the following powers:  (1) Organize the implementation of the systems and resolutions adopted by the members’ general assembly and the council;  (2) Preside over the day-to-day operations of the futures exchange;  (3) Draft implementing rules and measures pursuant to the articles of association and trading rules;  (4) Draft and implement approved development plans and annual work plans of the futures exchange;  (5) Draft the budgets and final accounts of the futures exchange;  (6) Draft plans for merger, division, dissolution, and liquidation of the futures exchange;  (7) Draft plans for the changes specified in Article 12 of these Measures;  (8) Decide on the organizational set-up of the futures exchange and hire and dismiss staff;  (9) Decide on staff remuneration and rewards and penalties;  (10) Other powers provided in the articles of association or conferred by the council.  Where the general manager is temporarily unable to perform duties, a deputy general manager designated by the general manager shall act in the general manager’s stead.**Article 30**  The appointment and removal of middle-level managers of a futures exchange shall be filed with the CSRC for the record.---# Chapter IV  Administration of Members**Article 31**  Members admitted by a futures exchange shall be corporate legal persons registered within the territory of the People’s Republic of China and shall have good credit standing.**Article 32**  Membership administration measures of a futures exchange shall include:  (1) Conditions and procedures for acquiring membership;  (2) Conditions and procedures for changing membership;  (3) Supervision and administration of members;  (4) Measures for handling members’ violations and defaults;  (5) Other matters that need to be provided for in the membership administration measures.**Article 33**  Members shall enjoy the following rights:  (1) Participate in the members’ general assembly and exercise rights to elect, to be elected, and to vote;  (2) Engage in futures trading on the exchange;  (3) Use the trading facilities provided by the exchange and obtain information and services related to futures trading;  (4) Transfer membership as prescribed;  (5) Jointly propose the convening of an extraordinary members’ meeting;  (6) Exercise the right to appeal in accordance with the articles of association and trading rules of the exchange;  (7) Other rights provided in the articles of association of the exchange.**Article 34**  Members shall perform the following obligations:  (1) Comply with relevant state laws, regulations, rules, and policies;  (2) Comply with the articles of association, business rules, and relevant decisions of the exchange;  (3) Pay various fees as prescribed;  (4) Implement resolutions of the members’ general assembly and the council;  (5) Accept the supervision and administration of the exchange;  (6) Other obligations provided in the articles of association of the exchange.**Article 35**  A futures exchange shall formulate seat administration rules. Members shall not, in whole or in part, lease, contract out, or otherwise permit other institutions or individuals to use their seats.**Article 36**  A futures exchange shall, each year, conduct sample or comprehensive inspections on members’ compliance with the business rules of the exchange and report the inspection results to the CSRC.  When exercising supervisory powers, a futures exchange may, within the scope of authority and procedures provided in its articles of association, trading rules, and implementing details, conduct investigations and collect evidence from members, and members shall cooperate.**Article 37**  A futures exchange may, based on the needs of trading and clearing business, establish special categories of members. The types of such special members, their qualification requirements, and their rights and obligations shall be provided for in the articles of association of the futures exchange.---# Chapter V  Basic Business Rules**Article 38**  A futures exchange shall collect margin from its members to secure the performance of futures contracts. The exchange shall open a dedicated settlement account with its designated clearing bank to hold margin funds on a segregated basis and shall not misappropriate such funds.**Article 39**  A futures exchange’s margin administration system shall include:  (1) The ratios and forms for collecting margin from members;  (2) The minimum balance of members’ margin in the dedicated settlement account;  (3) Disposal methods when a member’s margin balance falls below the minimum specified by the exchange.**Article 40**  A futures exchange shall allocate 20% of its fee income to a risk reserve fund, which shall be accounted for separately and held in a dedicated account.  The CSRC may, in light of the exchange’s business scale, development plan, and potential risks, determine the scale of the risk reserve fund.**Article 41**  Futures trading shall implement a daily mark-to-market settlement system.**Article 42**  Futures trading shall implement an investor trading code system. Futures brokerage company members and investors must comply with the “one account, one code” requirement and shall not mix codes in trading.**Article 43**  Futures trading shall implement a hedging position approval system and a speculative position limit system.  Where a non–futures brokerage company member or an investor applies for hedging positions, it/he shall submit materials such as scope of business, operating performance, and spot purchase-and-sale contracts to the futures exchange; the exchange shall determine the hedging positions upon review. Where an investor applies for hedging positions, the futures brokerage company member shall review the submitted materials and then submit them to the futures exchange for review.  The futures exchange shall formulate separate maximum position limit standards for speculative positions held by members and investors in non-delivery months and in delivery months.**Article 44**  Futures trading shall implement a large-position reporting system.  The futures exchange may formulate and adjust position reporting standards in light of market risk conditions.**Article 45**  Where there is reason to believe that a member or investor has violated the business rules of the futures exchange and is causing or is likely to cause a significant impact on the market, the exchange may, in order to prevent further expansion of the consequences of the violation, take the following temporary disposal measures against such member or investor:  (1) Restrict deposits;  (2) Restrict withdrawals;  (3) Restrict the opening of new positions;  (4) Raise margin ratios;  (5) Order position reduction within a specified time;  (6) Enforce forced liquidation.  Where a futures exchange takes the measures set out in items (4), (5), or (6) of the preceding paragraph in accordance with procedures prescribed by the business rules, it shall promptly report to the CSRC.  When taking temporary disposal measures, the futures exchange shall notify the member or investor in the manner prescribed by the business rules and specify the grounds for such measures.**Article 46**  When futures prices hit the up-limit or down-limit for several consecutive sessions in the same direction, the futures exchange may adopt measures such as adjusting the limit range, raising trading margin ratios, and reducing positions according to certain principles to defuse risks.**Article 47**  Where any of the following circumstances occurs during futures trading, the futures exchange may declare the occurrence of an abnormal situation and take emergency measures to defuse risks:  (1) Trading cannot proceed normally due to force majeure such as earthquake, flood, or fire, or for reasons not attributable to the exchange such as computer system failures;  (2) A member experiences a clearing or delivery crisis that is causing or is likely to cause a significant impact on the market;  (3) The circumstance described in Article 46 of these Measures occurs, and risks remain unresolved after corresponding measures have been taken;  (4) Other circumstances specified in the business rules of the exchange.  Before declaring the occurrence of an abnormal situation and deciding to take emergency measures, the futures exchange must report to the CSRC.**Article 48**  Where the exchange declares the occurrence of an abnormal situation and decides to suspend trading, the suspension shall not exceed three trading days, unless an extension is approved by the CSRC.**Article 49**  A futures exchange shall publish the following information in an appropriate manner:  (1) Real-time quotations;  (2) Rankings of open interest and trading volume;  (3) The number of standard warehouse receipts and available storage capacity;  (4) Other information specified in the business rules of the exchange.**Article 50**  A futures exchange shall compile weekly, monthly, and annual reports on trading conditions within its market and publish them in a timely manner.**Article 51**  A futures exchange shall keep records relating to futures trading, settlement, and delivery for not less than 20 years.---# Chapter VI  Supervision and Administration**Article 52**  A futures exchange shall formulate measures for investigating and handling violations of its business rules and submit them to the CSRC for approval.  Where members or investors commit violations related to futures business, the futures exchange shall promptly investigate and handle such violations within the scope of duties prescribed by the measures in the preceding paragraph; matters beyond such scope shall be reported to the CSRC.**Article 53**  When formulating or amending the implementing details of its trading rules, a futures exchange shall file them with the CSRC for the record.**Article 54**  Without the approval of the CSRC, the chair of the council, the general manager, and deputy general managers of a futures exchange shall not concurrently hold positions in any profit-making organization.  Non-member directors and staff of a futures exchange shall not, in any form, concurrently hold positions in member entities of the exchange or other profit-making entities related to futures trading.**Article 55**  Staff of a futures exchange shall consciously abide by relevant laws, regulations, rules, and policies; perform their duties faithfully and diligently; uphold honesty and creditworthiness; and possess good professional ethics.  Staff of a futures exchange shall not seek benefits from members of the exchange or from futures investors, and shall not, directly or indirectly, engage in futures trading.**Article 56**  A futures exchange shall fulfill the following reporting obligations to the CSRC:  (1) Within three months after the end of each year, submit financial accounting reports audited by an accounting firm with qualifications in securities and futures;  (2) Within 15 days after the end of each quarter and within 30 days after the end of each year, submit quarterly and annual work reports on its operations and on the implementation of relevant laws, regulations, rules, and policies;  (3) Other reporting matters as required by the CSRC.**Article 57**  Upon the occurrence of major events, a futures exchange shall promptly report to the CSRC.  “Major events,” as referred to in the preceding paragraph, include:  (1) Discovery that staff of the futures exchange are engaged in, or may be engaged in, serious violations of relevant state laws, regulations, rules, or policies;  (2) Litigation involving the futures exchange amounting to 10% or more of its net assets or having a significant impact on its operational risk;  (3) Other matters specified by the CSRC.**Article 58**  Where the CSRC deems that abnormal market conditions have arisen, it may decide to adopt necessary risk-disposal measures such as delayed market opening or suspension of trading.**Article 59**  Where the CSRC deems it necessary, it may issue reminders to senior management personnel of a futures exchange.**Article 60**  The CSRC may station inspectors at a futures exchange.
