期货交易所管理办法证监会令第42号第一章总则第三章组织机构第一节会员制期货交易所第二节公司制期货交易所第四章会员管理第五章基本业务规则第六章监督管理第七章法律责任144710121618第八章附则19第一章总则第一条为了加强对期货交易所的监督管理，明确期货交易所职责，维护期货市场秩序，促进期货市场积极稳妥发展，根据《期货交易管理条例》，制定本办法。第二条本办法适用于在中华人民共和国境内设立的期货交易所。第三条本办法所称期货交易所是指依照《期货交易管理条例》和本办法规定设立，不以营利为目的，履行《期货交易管理条例》和本办法规定的职责，按照章程和交易规则实行自律管理的法人。第四条经中国证券监督管理委员会（以下简称中国证监会）批准，期货交易所可以采取会员制或者公司制的组织形式。会员制期货交易所的注册资本划分为均等份额，由会员出资认缴。公司制期货交易所采用股份有限公司的组织形式。第五条中国证监会依法对期货交易所实行集中统一的监督管理。设立、变更与终止第六条设立期货交易所，由中国证监会审批。未经批准，任何单位或者个人不得设立期货交易所或者以任何形式组织期货交易及其相关活动。第七条经中国证监会批准设立的期货交易所，应当标明“商品交易所”或者“期货交易所”字样。其他任何单位或者个人不得使用期货交易所或者近似的名称。1第八条期货交易所除履行《期货交易管理条例》规定的职责外，还应当履行下列职责：（一）制定并实施期货交易所的交易规则及其实施细则；（二）发布市场信息；（三）监管会员及其客户、指定交割仓库、期货保证金存管银行及期货市场其他参与者的期货业务；（四）查处违规行为。第九条申请设立期货交易所，应当向中国证监会提交下列文件和材料：（一）申请书；（二）章程和交易规则草案；（三）期货交易所的经营计划；（四）拟加入会员或者股东名单；（五）理事会成员候选人或者董事会和监事会成员名单及简历；（六）拟任用高级管理人员的名单及简历；（七）场地、设备、资金证明文件及情况说明；（八）中国证监会规定的其他文件、材料。第十条期货交易所章程应当载明下列事项：（一）设立目的和职责；（二）名称、住所和营业场所；（三）注册资本及其构成；（四）营业期限；（五）组织机构的组成、职责、任期和议事规则；（六）管理人员的产生、任免及其职责；（七）基本业务制度；（八）风险准备金管理制度；（九）财务会计、内部控制制度；（十）变更、终止的条件、程序及清算办法；（十一）章程修改程序；（十二）需要在章程中规定的其他事项。第十一条除本办法第十条规定的事项外，会员制期货交易所章程还应当载明下列事项：（一）会员资格及其管理办法；（二）会员的权利和义务；（三）对会员的纪律处分。第十二条2期货交易所交易规则应当载明下列事项：（一）期货交易、结算和交割制度；（二）风险管理制度和交易异常情况的处理程序；（三）保证金的管理和使用制度；（四）期货交易信息的发布办法；（五）违规、违约行为及其处理办法；（六）交易纠纷的处理方式；（七）需要在交易规则中载明的其他事项。公司制期货交易所还应当在交易规则中载明本办法第十一条规定的事项。第十三条期货交易所变更名称、注册资本的，应当经中国证监会批准。第十四条期货交易所的合并、分立，由中国证监会批准。期货交易所合并可以采取吸收合并和新设合并两种方式，合并前各方的债权、债务由合并后存续或者新设的期货交易所承继。期货交易所分立的，其债权、债务由分立后的期货交易所承继。第十五条期货交易所联网交易的，应当于决定之日起10日内报告中国证监会。第十六条未经中国证监会批准，期货交易所不得设立分所或者其他任何期货交易场所。第十七条期货交易所因下列情形之一解散：（一）章程规定的营业期限届满；（二）会员大会或者股东大会决定解散；（三）中国证监会决定关闭。期货交易所因前款第（一）项、第（二）项情形解散的，由中国证监会批准。第十八条3期货交易所因合并、分立或者解散而终止的，由中国证监会予以公告。期货交易所终止的，应当成立清算组进行清算。清算组制定的清算方案，应当报中国证监会批准。第三章组织机构第一节会员制期货交易所第十九条会员制期货交易所设会员大会。会员大会是期货交易所的权力机构，由全体会员组成。第二十条会员大会行使下列职权：（一）审定期货交易所章程、交易规则及其修改草案；（二）选举和更换会员理事；（三）审议批准理事会和总经理的工作报告；（四）审议批准期货交易所的财务预算方案、决算报告；（五）审议期货交易所风险准备金使用情况；（六）决定增加或者减少期货交易所注册资本；（七）决定期货交易所的合并、分立、解散和清算事项；（八）决定期货交易所理事会提交的其他重大事项；（九）期货交易所章程规定的其他职权。第二十一条会员大会由理事会召集，每年召开一次。有下列情形之一的，应当召开临时会员大会：（一）会员理事不足期货交易所章程规定人数的2/3；（二）1/3以上会员联名提议；（三）理事会认为必要。第二十二条会员大会由理事长主持。召开会员大会，应当将会议审议的事项于会议召开10日前通知会员。临时会员大会不得对通知中未列明的事项作出决议。第二十三条会员大会有2/3以上会员参加方为有效。会员大会应当对表决事项制作会议纪要，由出席会议的理事签名。4会员大会结束之日起10日内，期货交易所应当将大会全部文件报告中国证监会。第二十四条期货交易所设理事会，每届任期3年。理事会是会员大会的常设机构，对会员大会负责。第二十五条理事会行使下列职权：（一）召集会员大会，并向会员大会报告工作；（二）拟订期货交易所章程、交易规则及其修改草案，提交会员大会审定；（三）审议总经理提出的财务预算方案、决算报告，提交会员大会通过；（四）审议期货交易所合并、分立、解散和清算的方案，提交会员大会通过；（五）决定专门委员会的设置；（六）决定会员的接纳和退出；（七）决定对违规行为的纪律处分；（八）决定期货交易所变更名称、住所或者营业场所；（九）审议批准根据章程和交易规则制定的细则和办法；（十）审议结算担保金的使用情况；（十一）审议批准风险准备金的使用方案；（十二）审议批准总经理提出的期货交易所发展规划和年度工作计划；（十三）审议批准期货交易所对外投资计划；（十四）监督总经理组织实施会员大会和理事会决议的情况；（十五）监督期货交易所高级管理人员和其他工作人员遵守国家有关法律、行政法规、规章、政策和期货交易所章程、交易规则及其实施细则的情况；（十六）组织期货交易所年度财务会计报告的审计工作，决定会计师事务所的聘用和变更事项；（十七）期货交易所章程规定和会员大会授予的其他职权。第二十六条理事会由会员理事和非会员理事组成；其中会员理事由会员大会选举产生，非会员理事由中国证监会委派。第二十七条理事会设理事长1人、副理事长1至2人。理事长、副理事长的任免，由中国证监会提名，理事会通过。理事长不得兼任总经理。第二十八条理事长行使下列职权：（一）主持会员大会、理事会会议和理事会日常工作；（二）组织协调专门委员会的工作；5（三）检查理事会决议的实施情况并向理事会报告。副理事长协助理事长工作。理事长因故临时不能履行职权的，由理事长指定的副理事长或者理事代其履行职权。第二十九条理事会会议至少每半年召开一次。每次会议应当于会议召开10日前通知全体理事。有下列情形之一的，应当召开理事会临时会议：（一）1/3以上理事联名提议；（二）期货交易所章程规定的情形；（三）中国证监会提议。理事会召开临时会议，可以另定召集理事会临时会议的通知方式和通知时限。第三十条理事会会议须有2/3以上理事出席方为有效，其决议须经全体理事1/2以上表决通过。理事会会议结束之日起10日内，理事会应当将会议决议及其他会议文件报告中国证监会。第三十一条理事会会议应当由理事本人出席。理事因故不能出席的，应当以书面形式委托其他理事代为出席；委托书中应当载明授权范围。每位理事只能接受一位理事的委托。理事会应当对会议表决事项作成会议记录，由出席会议的理事和记录员在会议记录上签名。第三十二条理事会可以根据需要设立监察、交易、结算、交割、会员资格审查、纪律处分、调解、财务和技术等专门委员会。各专门委员会对理事会负责，其职责、任期和人员组成等事项由理事会规定。第三十三条期货交易所设总经理1人，副总经理若干人。总经理、副总经理由中国证监会任免。总经理每届任期3年，连任不得超过两届。总经理是期货交易所的法定代表人，总经理是当然理事。第三十四条6总经理行使下列职权：（一）组织实施会员大会、理事会通过的制度和决议；（二）主持期货交易所的日常工作；（三）根据章程和交易规则拟订有关细则和办法；（四）决定结算担保金的使用；（五）拟订风险准备金的使用方案；（六）拟订并实施经批准的期货交易所发展规划、年度工作计划；（七）拟订并实施经批准的期货交易所对外投资计划；（八）拟订期货交易所财务预算方案、决算报告；（九）拟订期货交易所合并、分立、解散和清算的方案；（十）拟订期货交易所变更名称、住所或者营业场所的方案；（十一）决定期货交易所机构设置方案，聘任和解聘工作人员；（十二）决定期货交易所员工的工资和奖惩；（十三）期货交易所章程规定的或者理事会授予的其他职权。总经理因故临时不能履行职权的，由总经理指定的副总经理代其履行职权。第三十五条期货交易所任免中层管理人员，应当在决定之日起10日内向中国证监会报告。第二节公司制期货交易所第三十六条公司制期货交易所设股东大会。股东大会是期货交易所的权力机构，由全体股东组成。第三十七条股东大会行使下列职权：（一）本办法第二十条第（一）项、第（四）项至第（七）项规定的职权；（二）选举和更换非由职工代表担任的董事、监事；（三）审议批准董事会、监事会和总经理的工作报告；（四）决定期货交易所董事会提交的其他重大事项；（五）期货交易所章程规定的其他职权。第三十八条股东大会会议的召开及议事规则应当符合期货交易所章程的规定。会议结束之日起10日内，期货交易所应当将会议全部文件报告中国证监会。第三十九条7期货交易所设董事会，每届任期3年。第四十条董事会对股东大会负责，行使下列职权：（一）召集股东大会会议，并向股东大会报告工作；（二）拟订期货交易所章程、交易规则及其修改草案，提交股东大会审定；（三）审议总经理提出的财务预算方案、决算报告，提交股东大会通过；（四）审议期货交易所合并、分立、解散和清算的方案，提交股东大会通过；（五）监督总经理组织实施股东大会和董事会决议的情况；（六）本办法第二十五条第（五）项至第（十三）项、第（十五）项、第（十六）项规定的职权；（七）期货交易所章程规定和股东大会授予的其他职权。第四十一条期货交易所设董事长1人，副董事长1至2人。董事长、副董事长的任免，由中国证监会提名，董事会通过。董事长不得兼任总经理。第四十二条董事长行使下列职权：（一）主持股东大会、董事会会议和董事会日常工作；（二）组织协调专门委员会的工作；（三）检查董事会决议的实施情况并向董事会报告。副董事长协助董事长工作。董事长因故临时不能履行职权的，由董事长指定的副董事长或者董事代其履行职权。第四十三条董事会会议的召开和议事规则应当符合期货交易所章程的规定。董事会会议结束之日起10日内，董事会应当将会议决议及其他会议文件报告中国证监会。第四十四条董事会可以根据需要设立本办法第三十二条规定的专门委员会。各专门委员会对董事会负责，其职责、任期和人员组成等事项由董事会规定。第四十五条期货交易所应当设独立董事。独立董事由中国证监会提名，股东大会通过。8第四十六条期货交易所可以设董事会秘书。董事会秘书由中国证监会提名，董事会通过。董事会秘书负责期货交易所股东大会和董事会会议的筹备、文件保管以及期货交易所股东资料的管理等事宜。第四十七条期货交易所设总经理1人，副总经理若干人。总经理、副总经理由中国证监会任免。总经理每届任期3年，连任不得超过两届。总经理是期货交易所的法定代表人，总经理应当由董事担任。第四十八条总经理行使下列职权：（一）组织实施股东大会、董事会通过的制度和决议；（二）本办法第三十四条第（二）项至第（十二）项规定的职权；（三）期货交易所章程规定或者董事会授予的其他职权。总经理因故临时不能履行职权的，由总经理指定的副总经理代其履行职权。第四十九条期货交易所设监事会，每届任期3年。监事会成员不得少于3人。监事会设主席1人，副主席1至2人。监事会主席、副主席的任免，由中国证监会提名，监事会通过。第五十条监事会行使下列职权：（一）检查期货交易所财务；（二）监督期货交易所董事、高级管理人员执行职务行为；（三）向股东大会会议提出提案；（四）期货交易所章程规定的其他职权。第五十一条监事会会议的召开和议事规则应当符合期货交易所章程的规定。监事会会议结束之日起10日内，监事会应当将会议决议及其他会议文件报告中国证监会。第五十二条9本办法第三十五条的规定适用于公司制期货交易所。第四章会员管理第五十三条期货交易所会员应当是在中华人民共和国境内登记注册的企业法人或者其他经济组织。第五十四条取得期货交易所会员资格，应当经期货交易所批准。期货交易所批准、取消会员的会员资格，应当向中国证监会报告。第五十五条期货交易所应当制定会员管理办法，规定会员资格的取得与终止的条件和程序、对会员的监督管理等内容。第五十六条会员制期货交易所会员享有下列权利：（一）参加会员大会，行使选举权、被选举权和表决权；（二）在期货交易所从事规定的交易、结算和交割等业务；（三）使用期货交易所提供的交易设施，获得有关期货交易的信息和服务；（四）按规定转让会员资格；（五）联名提议召开临时会员大会；（六）按照期货交易所章程和交易规则行使申诉权；（七）期货交易所章程规定的其他权利。第五十七条会员制期货交易所会员应当履行下列义务：（一）遵守国家有关法律、行政法规、规章和政策；（二）遵守期货交易所的章程、交易规则及其实施细则及有关决定；（三）按规定缴纳各种费用；（四）执行会员大会、理事会的决议；（五）接受期货交易所监督管理。第五十八条公司制期货交易所会员享有下列权利：（一）本办法第五十六条第（二）项和第（三）项规定的权利；10（二）按照交易规则行使申诉权；（三）期货交易所交易规则规定的其他权利。第五十九条公司制期货交易所会员应当履行本办法第五十七条第（一）项至第（三）项、第（五）项规定的义务。第六十条期货交易所每年应当对会员遵守期货交易所交易规则及其实施细则的情况进行抽样或者全面检查，并将检查结果报告中国证监会。期货交易所行使监管职权时，可以按照期货交易所章程和交易规则及其实施细则规定的权限和程序对会员进行调查取证，会员应当配合。第六十一条经中国证监会批准，期货交易所可以实行全员结算制度或者会员分级结算制度。第六十二条实行全员结算制度的期货交易所会员均具有与期货交易所进行结算的资格。第六十三条实行全员结算制度的期货交易所会员由期货公司会员和非期货公司会员组成。期货公司会员按照中国证监会批准的业务范围开展相关业务；非期货公司会员不得从事《期货交易管理条例》规定的期货公司业务。第六十四条实行全员结算制度的期货交易所对会员结算，会员对其受托的客户结算。第六十五条实行会员分级结算制度的期货交易所会员由结算会员和非结算会员组成。结算会员具有与期货交易所进行结算的资格，非结算会员不具有与期货交易所进行结算的资格。期货交易所对结算会员结算，结算会员对非结算会员结算，非结算会员对其受托的客户结算。第六十六条结算会员由交易结算会员、全面结算会员和特别结算会员组成。11全面结算会员、特别结算会员可以为与其签订结算协议的非结算会员办理结算业务。交易结算会员不得为非结算会员办理结算业务。第六十七条申请成为结算会员的，应当取得中国证监会批准的结算业务资格。第六十八条实行会员分级结算制度的期货交易所可以根据结算会员资信和业务开展情况，限制结算会员的结算业务范围，但应当于3日内报告中国证监会。第五章基本业务规则第六十九条期货交易所向会员收取的保证金，只能用于担保期货合约的履行，不得查封、冻结、扣划或者强制执行。期货交易所应当在期货保证金存管银行开立专用结算账户，专户存储保证金，不得挪用。保证金分为结算准备金和交易保证金。结算准备金是指未被合约占用的保证金；交易保证金是指已被合约占用的保证金。实行会员分级结算制度的期货交易所只向结算会员收取保证金。第七十条期货交易所应当建立保证金管理制度。保证金管理制度应当包括下列内容：（一）向会员收取保证金的标准和形式；（二）专用结算账户中会员结算准备金最低余额；（三）当会员结算准备金余额低于期货交易所规定最低余额时的处置方法。会员结算准备金最低余额由会员以自有资金向期货交易所缴纳。第七十一条期货交易所可以接受以下有价证券充抵保证金：（一）经期货交易所认定的标准仓单；（二）可流通的国债；（三）中国证监会认定的其他有价证券。以前款规定的有价证券充抵保证金的，充抵的期限不得超过该有价证券的有效期限。12第七十二条标准仓单充抵保证金的，期货交易所以充抵日前一交易日该标准仓单对应品种最近交割月份期货合约的结算价为基准计算价值。国债充抵保证金的，期货交易所以充抵日前一交易日该国债在上海证券交易所、深圳证券交易所较低的收盘价为基准计算价值。期货交易所可以根据市场情况对用于充抵保证金的有价证券的基准计算价值进行调整。第七十三条有价证券充抵保证金的金额不得高于以下标准中的较低值：（一）有价证券基准计算价值的80％；（二）会员在期货交易所专用结算账户中的实有货币资金的4倍。第七十四条期货交易的相关亏损、费用、货款和税金等款项，应当以货币资金支付，不得以有价证券充抵的金额支付。第七十五条客户以有价证券充抵保证金的，会员应当将收到的有价证券提交期货交易所。非结算会员的客户以有价证券充抵保证金的，非结算会员应将收到的有价证券提交结算会员，由结算会员提交期货交易所。第七十六条客户以有价证券充抵保证金的，期货交易所应当将用于充抵的有价证券的种类和数量如实反映在该客户的交易编码下。第七十七条实行会员分级结算制度的期货交易所应当建立结算担保金制度。结算担保金包括基础结算担保金和变动结算担保金。结算担保金由结算会员以自有资金向期货交易所缴纳。结算担保金属于结算会员所有，用于应对结算会员违约风险。期货交易所应当按照有关规定管理和使用，不得挪作他用。期货交易所调整基础结算担保金标准的，应当在调整前报告中国证监会。第七十八条13期货交易所应当按照手续费收入的20％的比例提取风险准备金，风险准备金应当单独核算，专户存储。中国证监会可以根据期货交易所业务规模、发展计划以及潜在的风险决定风险准备金的规模。第七十九条期货交易实行客户交易编码制度。会员和客户应当遵守一户一码制度，不得混码交易。第八十条期货交易实行限仓制度和套期保值审批制度。第八十一条期货交易实行大户持仓报告制度。会员或者客户持仓达到期货交易所规定的持仓报告标准的，会员或者客户应当向期货交易所报告。客户未报告的，会员应当向期货交易所报告。期货交易所可以根据市场风险状况制定并调整持仓报告标准。第八十二条期货交易实行当日无负债结算制度。第八十三条实行全员结算制度的期货交易所对会员进行风险管理，会员对其受托的客户进行风险管理。实行会员分级结算制度的期货交易所对结算会员进行风险管理，结算会员对与其签订结算协议的非结算会员进行风险管理，会员对其受托的客户进行风险管理。第八十四条会员在期货交易中违约的，应当承担违约责任。期货交易所先以违约会员的保证金承担该会员的违约责任，保证金不足的，实行全员结算制度的期货交易所应当以违约会员的自有资金、期货交易所风险准备金和期货交易所自有资金承担；实行会员分级结算制度的期货交易所应当以违约会员的自有资金、结算担保金、期货交易所风险准备金和期货交易所自有资金承担。期货交易所以结算担保金、期货交易所风险准备金和期货交易所自有资金代为承担责任后，由此取得对违约会员的相应追偿权。14第八十五条有根据认为会员或者客户违反期货交易所交易规则及其实施细则并且对市场正在产生或者即将产生重大影响，为防止违规行为后果进一步扩大，期货交易所可以对该会员或者客户采取下列临时处置措施：（一）限制入金；（二）限制出金；（三）限制开仓；（四）提高保证金标准；（五）限期平仓；（六）强行平仓。期货交易所按交易规则及其实施细则规定的程序采取前款第（四）项、第（五）项或者第（六）项措施的，应当在采取措施后及时报告中国证监会。期货交易所对会员或者客户采取临时处置措施，应当按照期货交易所交易规则及其实施细则规定的方式通知会员或者客户，并列明采取临时处置措施的根据。第八十六条期货价格出现同方向连续涨跌停板的，期货交易所可以采用调整涨跌停板幅度、提高交易保证金标准及按一定原则减仓等措施化解风险。第八十七条期货交易所实行风险警示制度。期货交易所认为必要的，可以分别或同时采取要求会员和客户报告情况、谈话提醒、发布风险提示函等措施，以警示和化解风险。第八十八条在期货交易过程中出现以下情形之一的，期货交易所可以宣布进入异常情况，采取紧急措施化解风险：（一）地震、水灾、火灾等不可抗力或者计算机系统故障等不可归责于期货交易所的原因导致交易无法正常进行；（二）会员出现结算、交割危机，对市场正在产生或者即将产生重大影响；（三）出现本办法第八十六条规定的情形经采取相应措施后仍未化解风险；（四）期货交易所交易规则及其实施细则中规定的其他情形。期货交易所宣布进入异常情况并决定采取紧急措施前应当报告中国证监会。第八十九条期货交易所宣布进入异常情况并决定暂停交易的，暂停交易的期限不得超过3个交易日，但经中国证监会批准延长的除外。15第九十条期货交易所应当以适当方式发布下列信息：（一）即时行情；（二）持仓量、成交量排名情况；（三）期货交易所交易规则及其实施细则规定的其他信息。期货交易涉及商品实物交割的，期货交易所还应当发布标准仓单数量和可用库容情况。第九十一条期货交易所应当编制交易情况周报表、月报表和年报表，并及时公布。第九十二条期货交易所对期货交易、结算、交割资料的保存期限应当不少于20年。第六章监督管理第九十三条期货交易所制定或者修改章程、交易规则，上市、中止、取消或者恢复交易品种，上市、修改或者终止合约，应当经中国证监会批准。第九十四条期货交易所应当对违反期货交易所交易规则及其实施细则的行为制定查处办法，并报中国证监会批准。期货交易所对会员及其客户、指定交割仓库、期货保证金存管银行及期货市场其他参与者与期货业务有关的违规行为，应当在前款所称办法规定的职责范围内及时予以查处；超出前款所称办法规定的职责范围的，应当向中国证监会报告。第九十五条期货交易所制定或者修改交易规则的实施细则，应当征求中国证监会的意见，并在正式发布实施前，报告中国证监会。第九十六条期货交易所的交易结算系统和交易结算业务应当满足期货保证金安全存管监控的要求，真实、准确和完整地反映会员保证金的变动情况。第九十七条16期货交易所应当按照中国证监会有关期货保证金安全存管监控的规定，向期货保证金安全存管监控机构报送相关信息。第九十八条公司制期货交易所收购本期货交易所股份、股东转让所持股份或者对其股份进行其他处置，应当经中国证监会批准。第九十九条期货交易所的高级管理人员应当具备中国证监会要求的条件。未经中国证监会批准，期货交易所的理事长、副理事长、董事长、副董事长、监事会主席、监事会副主席、总经理、副总经理、董事会秘书不得在任何营利性组织中兼职。未经批准，期货交易所的其他工作人员和非会员理事不得以任何形式在期货交易所会员单位及其他与期货交易有关的营利性组织兼职。第一百条期货交易所工作人员应当自觉遵守有关法律、行政法规、规章和政策，恪尽职守，勤勉尽责，诚实信用，具有良好的职业操守。期货交易所工作人员不得从事期货交易，不得泄漏内幕消息或者利用内幕消息获得非法利益，不得从期货交易所会员、客户处谋取利益。期货交易所的工作人员履行职务，遇有与本人或者其亲属有利害关系的情形时，应当回避。第一百零一条期货交易所的所得收益按照国家有关规定管理和使用，但应当首先用于保证期货交易场所、设施的运行和改善。第一百零二条期货交易所应当向中国证监会履行下列报告义务：（一）每一年度结束后4个月内提交经具有证券、期货相关业务资格的会计师事务所审计的年度财务报告；（二）每一季度结束后15日内、每一年度结束后30日内提交有关经营情况和有关法律、行政法规、规章、政策执行情况的季度和年度工作报告；（三）中国证监会规定的其他事项。第一百零三条17发生下列重大事项，期货交易所应当及时向中国证监会报告：（一）发现期货交易所工作人员存在或者可能存在严重违反国家有关法律、行政法规、规章、政策的行为；（二）期货交易所涉及占其净资产10％以上或者对其经营风险有较大影响的诉讼；（三）期货交易所的重大财务支出、投资事项以及可能带来较大财务或者经营风险的重大财务决策；（四）中国证监会规定的其他事项。第一百零四条中国证监会可以根据市场情况调整期货交易所收取的保证金标准，暂停、恢复或者取消某一期货交易品种的交易。第一百零五条中国证监会认为期货市场出现异常情况的，可以决定采取延迟开市、暂停交易、提前闭市等必要的风险处置措施。第一百零六条中国证监会认为有必要的，可以对期货交易所高级管理人员实施提示。第一百零七条中国证监会派出机构对期货交易所会员进行风险处置，采取监管措施的，经中国证监会批准，期货交易所应当在限制会员资金划转、限制会员开仓、移仓和强行平仓等方面予以配合。第一百零八条中国证监会可以向期货交易所派驻督察员。督察员依照中国证监会的有关规定履行职责。督察员履行职责，期货交易所应当予以配合。第一百零九条期货交易所应当按照国家有关规定及时缴纳期货市场监管费。第七章法律责任第一百一十条期货交易所未按照本办法第十五条、第三十五条、第五十二条、第六十八条、第八十八条、第九十五条、第一百零二条和第一百零三条的规定履行报告义务，或者未按照本办法第二十三条、第三十条、第三十八条、第四十三条、第五十一条和第九十七条的规定报送有关文件、资料18和信息的，根据《期货交易管理条例》第六十八条处罚。第一百一十一条期货交易所有下列行为之一的，根据《期货交易管理条例》第六十九条处罚：（一）未经批准变更名称或者注册资本；（二）未经批准设立分所或者其他任何交易场所；（三）违反有价证券充抵保证金规定；（四）不按照规定对会员进行检查；（五）未建立或者未执行客户交易编码制度、保证金管理制度；（六）交易结算系统和交易结算业务不符合本办法第九十六条的规定。第一百一十二条期货交易所工作人员违反本办法第一百条规定的，根据《期货交易管理条例》第八十二条处罚。第八章附则第一百一十三条在中国证监会批准的其他交易场所进行期货交易的，依照本办法的有关规定执行。第一百一十四条本办法自2007年4月15日起施行。2002年5月17日发布的《期货交易所管理办法》（中国证券监督管理委员会令第6号）同时废止。19

name_chn: 期货经纪公司管理办法（证监期货字〔1999〕43号）
text: # Measures for the Administration of Futures Brokerage Companies  (“Zhengjian Qihuo Zi [1999] No. 43”)## Chapter I  General Provisions**Article 1**  To regulate futures brokerage activities, strengthen the supervision and administration of futures brokerage companies, and protect the lawful rights and interests of futures investors, these Measures are formulated pursuant to the *Interim Regulations on the Administration of Futures Trading*.**Article 2**  These Measures apply to futures brokerage activities conducted within the territory of the People’s Republic of China.**Article 3**  “Futures brokerage,” as used in these Measures, refers to the business activity whereby, upon a client’s entrustment and according to the client’s instructions, a broker executes futures trades in its own name for the client, charges handling fees, and the trading results are borne by the client.**Article 4**  Any entity operating futures brokerage business must be a futures brokerage company lawfully established.  No other entity or individual may operate futures brokerage business.**Article 5**  The China Securities Regulatory Commission (hereinafter, the “CSRC”) shall, in accordance with law, exercise centralized and unified supervision and administration over all futures brokerage companies nationwide.  The CSRC’s local offices—regional securities regulatory offices, agencies, and resident commissioners’ offices (hereinafter, the “CSRC local offices”)—shall regulate futures brokerage companies in accordance with these Measures and as authorized by the CSRC.---## Chapter II  Establishment, Change, and Termination### Section 1  Establishment**Article 6**  The establishment of a futures brokerage company is subject to CSRC approval. Without approval, no entity or individual may establish or in a disguised form establish a futures brokerage company.  A futures brokerage company’s name shall include the words “Futures Brokerage.” No other entity or individual may use “Futures Brokerage” or similar wording.**Article 7**  A futures brokerage company may engage in futures brokerage and other businesses approved by the CSRC.  A futures brokerage company shall not engage in businesses beyond its approved scope; shall not become an investor bearing unlimited liability; shall not speculate in stocks in violation of regulations; and, except for providing the performance guarantee stipulated in Article 44 of the *Interim Regulations on the Administration of Futures Trading*, shall not provide guarantees for others.**Article 8**  To establish a futures brokerage company, the following conditions shall be met:  (1) Minimum registered capital of RMB 30 million, of which cash contribution shall be no less than RMB 18 million;  (2) A standardized articles of association;  (3) Senior management personnel who meet qualification requirements;  (4) At least 15 other practitioners holding practice qualifications;  (5) A sound organizational structure and management systems;  (6) Brokerage business rules, financial and accounting systems, risk management and internal control systems that meet requirements;  (7) Business premises and other facilities that meet requirements;  (8) Other conditions prescribed by laws, regulations, and the CSRC.**Article 9**  Shareholders of a futures brokerage company must be PRC enterprise legal persons and comply with applicable laws, regulations, rules, and policies.**Article 10**  An applicant for establishment shall first submit to the CSRC:  (1) An application stating the proposed company’s name, domicile, business premises, registered capital, etc.;  (2) A feasibility report;  (3) Other materials required by the CSRC.**Article 11**  After preliminary approval, the applicant shall conduct preparation in accordance with the *Company Law* and these Measures. If the conditions in Article 8 are met, the applicant shall submit to the CSRC:  (1) Draft articles of association;  (2) Shareholder register and details of capital contributions;  (3) Audited financial reports of shareholders for the most recent two years by an accounting firm with appropriate qualifications;  (4) Capital verification certificate issued by a statutory capital verification institution;  (5) Risk disclosure statement for futures trading, a standard futures brokerage agreement, brokerage business rules, financial system, risk management and internal control systems;  (6) Lists of proposed directors and supervisors, list of senior managers with proof of qualification;  (7) Lists of other proposed employees with practice qualifications;  (8) Proof of ownership or right to use business premises;  (9) Description of facilities related to the brokerage business;  (10) Pre-approval of name from the State Administration for Industry and Commerce (SAIC);  (11) Other materials required by the CSRC.**Article 12**  A futures brokerage company may establish business departments (branches) as needed, subject to CSRC approval.  A business department does not have legal person status; it conducts business within the scope authorized by the company, and the company bears its civil liabilities.  The business department’s name must read “×× Futures Brokerage Co., Ltd. ×× Business Department.”**Article 13**  To apply to establish a business department, a company shall meet:  (1) No major violations in the preceding year;  (2) Good operating performance at already approved business departments;  (3) Managerial personnel that meet requirements and at least three other practitioners;  (4) Complete management systems for business departments;  (5) Business premises and facilities that meet requirements;  (6) Other conditions prescribed by the CSRC.**Article 14**  To apply to establish a business department, the company shall first submit to the CSRC:  (1) An application stating the proposed name and business premises;  (2) A feasibility report;  (3) Other materials required by the CSRC.**Article 15**  After preliminary approval, the applicant shall prepare for establishment and, upon meeting Article 13 conditions, submit to the CSRC:  (1) Audited financial report of the applicant for the preceding year;  (2) Shareholders’ meeting or board resolution on establishing the business department;  (3) Practice qualification certificates of proposed staff of the business department;  (4) Proof of ownership or right to use the premises;  (5) Description of facilities related to the brokerage business;  (6) Opinions of the CSRC local office where the company is located;  (7) The company’s risk management, internal control and other management systems applicable to the business department;  (8) Other materials required by the CSRC.**Article 16**  A business department shall not be established through joint ventures or cooperation; shall not be contracted out or leased; and shall not set up additional business premises.**Article 17**  A futures brokerage company shall not, under the guise of a “representative office,” “liaison office,” etc., in effect establish a business department to engage in brokerage business.**Article 18**  Applications to establish a company or business department shall be preliminarily reviewed by the CSRC local office at the proposed place of establishment.  Where the local office decides to approve, it shall issue a preliminary opinion and submit it to the CSRC for approval; where it decides not to approve, it shall provide a written explanation to the applicant.**Article 19**  Within one month from receipt of compliant application materials, the CSRC shall notify the applicant in writing whether approval is granted. If not approved, reasons shall be stated.**Article 20**  In reviewing applications, the CSRC and its local offices shall consider the needs of market development and the geographic layout of the brokerage industry.**Article 21**  Upon obtaining a *Futures Brokerage Business License* or a *Business Department Operating License* from the CSRC, the applicant shall file for registration with the SAIC within 90 days and obtain a business license.  If, without just cause, registration is not completed within 90 days of obtaining the license, the license becomes void.**Article 22**  Where a company or business department fails to commence business within six months after obtaining its business license, or voluntarily ceases business for six consecutive months after opening, its license shall be revoked, unless otherwise approved by the CSRC.**Article 23**  Within 30 days of obtaining its business license, a company or business department shall file with the CSRC and the local CSRC office where it is located; for cross-region business departments, the company shall also file with the CSRC local office where the head office is located within 30 days of the business department obtaining its license.### Section 2  Changes**Article 24**  Any of the following changes by a futures brokerage company shall be subject to CSRC approval:  (1) Amendments to the articles of association;  (2) Change of legal representative;  (3) Change of shareholders or equity structure;  (4) Increase or decrease of registered capital;  (5) Change of domicile or business premises of the company or any business department;  (6) Revocation of a business department;  (7) Merger or division;  (8) Other matters prescribed by the CSRC.**Article 25**  Changes to the chair, vice chair, general manager, or deputy general manager shall be submitted to the CSRC for review of appointees’ qualifications.**Article 26**  Where a company changes its name, it shall apply to the SAIC for change of registration and, within 15 days from obtaining the new business license, apply to the CSRC to change its Futures Brokerage Business License; failure to do so renders the license void.**Article 27**  For change approval, a company shall submit a change application, the shareholders’ or board resolution on the change, and other materials required by the CSRC.**Article 28**  Change applications shall be preliminarily reviewed by the CSRC local office where the company is located.  Revocation of a business department shall be preliminarily reviewed by the CSRC local office where the business department is located.  Changes of domicile or business premises shall be preliminarily reviewed by the CSRC local office of the new location.**Article 29**  Where a local office decides to approve a change, it shall issue a preliminary opinion and submit to the CSRC for approval; where it decides not to approve, it shall provide a written explanation.  Within one month after receipt of compliant change materials, the CSRC shall notify the applicant in writing whether approval is granted; if not, reasons shall be stated.**Article 30**  For capital increase, in addition to the materials in Article 27, the company shall submit:  (1) Capital increase plan;  (2) List of new shareholders, copies of business licenses, their contribution methods and amounts, and their prior-year audited financial statements;  (3) Capital verification certificate;  (4) Post-increase equity proportions.  New shareholders must meet the shareholder conditions in Article 9.**Article 31**  For mergers, in addition to Article 27 materials, the company shall submit:  (1) Merger agreement;  (2) Merger feasibility report;  (3) Balance sheets and property inventories of all parties.**Article 32**  A merger agreement shall include:  (1) Names, domiciles, and legal representatives of all parties;  (2) Merger method and conditions;  (3) Equity proportions of parties in a newly established company (for new establishment mergers);  (4) Assumption and settlement of debts and claims;  (5) Asset transfer method or asset changes;  (6) Succession or changes concerning business departments;  (7) Liability for breach;  (8) Time and place of execution.**Article 33**  A company shall apply for change of shareholders or equity structure under any of the following:  (1) Equity transfer by agreement among shareholders;  (2) Equity transfer by a shareholder to another transferee;  (3) Agreed adjustment of registered capital resulting in equity structure change;  (4) Equity pledge where the pledgee acquires equity pursuant to law or contract;  (5) A shareholder’s dissolution, termination, or revocation where the transferee lawfully acquires the equity;  (6) Other causes of equity change.**Article 34**  For equity change, in addition to Article 27 materials, the company shall submit:  (1) Equity transfer agreement;  (2) Amended articles of association;  (3) Post-change list of board members.**Article 35**  An equity transfer agreement shall include:  (1) Names, domiciles, and legal representatives of transferor and transferee;  (2) Proportion and conditions of the equity transferred;  (3) Term and method of transfer;  (4) Rights and obligations of both parties;  (5) Liability for breach;  (6) Time and place of execution.  The transferee must meet the shareholder conditions in Article 9.**Article 36**  Within 30 days of approval, the company shall, with the changed license for the company or business department, complete change registration with the SAIC and, within 30 days thereafter, file with the CSRC; failure to make the changes renders the license void.**Article 37**  Where a company or business department changes domicile or business premises, or where a company changes its name or revokes a business department, it shall publish an announcement within 10 days of approval in major local newspapers or CSRC-recognized industry media; if premises change, a notice shall also be posted at the original site.### Section 3  Dissolution and Liquidation**Article 38**  A futures brokerage company shall be terminated upon any of the following:  (1) Expiry of business term or occurrence of a dissolution event specified in the articles;  (2) Resolution of the shareholders’ meeting;  (3) Dissolution due to merger or division;  (4) Closure ordered by law;  (5) Bankruptcy declared by law.  For dissolution under items (1)–(3), the company shall apply to the CSRC local office and attach reasons and a plan for handling clients’ positions and margins; dissolution shall be effective upon approval.**Article 39**  Upon dissolution, a liquidation group shall be formed to conduct liquidation pursuant to law. The CSRC local office shall supervise the handling of clients’ positions and margins.**Article 40**  During liquidation, the group shall formulate a plan, clean up property, prepare balance sheets and property inventories, handle claims and debts, collect capital contributions subscribed but unpaid, settle taxes, and dispose of remaining property.  Clients’ positions shall be handled and clients’ margins returned on a priority basis.**Article 41**  Where a business department is revoked, the company shall lawfully handle that department’s clients’ positions and shall first return clients’ margins.  Before completing the handling of clients’ positions and margins, the department’s assets shall not be transferred.**Article 42**  Within 10 days of completing liquidation, the company shall return its Futures Brokerage Business License; overdue returns shall be cancelled by the CSRC.  The company shall proceed with deregistration at the SAIC.---## Chapter III  Basic Rules of Futures Brokerage Business### Section 1  General Provisions**Article 43**  A futures brokerage company shall comply with applicable laws, regulations, rules, and CSRC provisions; manipulation of futures prices, insider trading, and defrauding clients are prohibited.**Article 44**  A futures brokerage company shall adhere to the principles of openness, fairness, impartiality, and good faith, safeguard clients’ lawful rights and interests, and ensure sound market operation.**Article 45**  A futures brokerage company shall execute client orders with appropriate skill, due care, and diligence to protect client interests.**Article 46**  A futures brokerage company shall avoid any conflict of interest with clients and ensure fair treatment of all clients.**Article 47**  A futures brokerage company shall continuously maintain qualified personnel and technological facilities, implement internal rules, and ensure sound and lawful operations.**Article 48**  A futures brokerage company shall explain to clients the risks of futures trading and keep at its business premises the relevant laws and regulations, exchange trading rules, and its brokerage business rules and implementing details for client inspection.### Section 2  Futures Brokerage Agreement**Article 49**  A futures brokerage agreement is a written agreement between the client and the company setting forth rights and obligations.  Clients include entities and individuals. An entity shall not sign an agreement in the name of an individual, nor an individual in the name of an entity.  “Entities” include companies, enterprises, and other economic organizations.**Article 50**  A futures brokerage agreement shall include:  (1) Client’s name, ID number, domicile, phone number (for entities: name, legal representative or principal, domicile, phone number);  (2) Client’s contact address and method, means of giving and confirming orders;  (3) Account management and clearing methods;  (4) Handling of the client’s account when the company is unable to engage in brokerage business;  (5) Margin standards and payment methods;  (6) Conditions for margin calls and the timing and means of notice;  (7) Conditions for forced liquidation and related arrangements;  (8) Brokerage commissions and other related fees;  (9) Methods of delivery and confirmation of trade confirmations and monthly statements;  (10) Scope of advisory, training, and other services;  (11) Exemption clauses;  (12) Dispute resolution;  (13) Amendment and termination of the contract;  (14) Other matters prescribed by the CSRC.**Article 51**  A company’s standard brokerage agreement must conform to the CSRC’s model contract and be submitted to the CSRC local office for review.**Article 52**  None of the following may become a client of a futures brokerage company:  (1) Natural persons without or with limited civil capacity;  (2) Staff of futures regulatory authorities or futures exchanges;  (3) Employees of the company and their spouses or lineal relatives;  (4) Persons barred from entering the futures market;  (5) Financial institutions, public institutions, and state organs;  (6) State-owned enterprises, or enterprises in which state-owned assets hold a controlling or leading position, that fail to provide approval documents signed by the legal representative;  (7) Entity accounts opened by entrustment without providing the entrustment authorization documents;  (8) Other situations as prescribed by the CSRC.**Article 53**  Before signing, the company shall inquire into and, where necessary, require proof of the client’s eligibility, source of funds, and other credit-related matters; the client shall truthfully disclose and provide information.  Where a client intentionally conceals facts or, due to negligence, fails to fulfill the disclosure obligation, the company shall refuse to open an account or may terminate the contract; losses shall be borne by the client, and handling fees will not be refunded.**Article 54**  The client shall specify in the contract the authorized agent(s) to place orders, transfer funds, etc., agree on contact methods, and deposit specimen signatures.  Changes shall be notified in writing to the company and take effect upon confirmation.**Article 55**  Under any of the following, the company may terminate the agreement, settle the client’s account, and close it:  (1) The client dies, loses civil capacity, or terminates (for entities);  (2) The client is declared by a people’s court to enter bankruptcy proceedings;  (3) Other circumstances prescribed by the CSRC.**Article 56**  A client may terminate the entrustment by closing the account in accordance with required procedures.**Article 57**  When closing an account, the company shall settle all claims and debts with the client.### Section 3  Basic Rules of Brokerage Operations**Article 58**  A company must accept client orders and conduct futures trading at lawfully established business premises.**Article 59**  Publicity regarding a company’s credit standing must be truthful; inducing clients through false publicity is prohibited.  A company shall not cite the CSRC’s business license as a guarantee of its operational capability or financial soundness.**Article 60**  Advertising must comply with CSRC provisions; promotional materials must be signed by the legal representative or an authorized person and filed with the CSRC local office.**Article 61**  Operational activities shall be conducted by staff who hold practice qualifications pursuant to the *Measures for the Administration of Qualifications for Futures Practitioners*.**Article 62**  Before opening an account, the company shall present the *Futures Trading Risk Disclosure Statement*; after the client signs to acknowledge understanding, the written brokerage agreement may be signed.  The format and content of the Risk Disclosure Statement are unified by the CSRC.  A company shall not open an account for a client without a written agreement.**Article 63**  Before signing, the company shall explain the meaning of the contract terms; after the client clearly understands the parties’ rights and obligations, the client shall sign to confirm.**Article 64**  The company shall assign client trading codes in accordance with exchange coding rules and file them with the exchange.  Cancellation of a client code shall be filed with the exchange.**Article 65**  Clients must open accounts under their true identity.  Individual clients must present PRC identity documents; entity clients must provide lawful certificates evidencing PRC legal-person or other economic-organization status.  The company shall verify the authenticity of client identity.**Article 66**  A company shall not, under any pretext, open an account in its own name at itself or another brokerage to engage in futures trading.**Article 67**  The company shall establish client account-opening files and keep them confidential except as required by law for inspection.**Article 68**  The company shall keep a “error-order log” to record the handling of erroneous orders.**Article 69**  The company shall establish and improve a client complaint handling system and archive complaints and their dispositions.**Article 70**  The company shall collect margins from clients and keep detailed margin sub-ledgers.**Article 71**  The company shall open a client margin account at the clearing bank designated by the exchange, to hold client margins.  Such accounts shall be filed with the CSRC local office and be subject to lawful inspection.**Article 72**  A company may set the client trading margin ratio, which shall be at least 3 percentage points higher than the margin ratio the exchange charges the company.  The company may adjust margin ratios reasonably according to risk and shall notify clients as agreed in the brokerage contract.**Article 73**  A company may agree with the client on trading risk control conditions.  Where the client’s margin is insufficient and risk reaches the agreed condition, the company shall notify the client to add margin as agreed; if the client fails to do so in time, the company may forcibly close some or all positions until the balance meets the agreed risk control condition.  Where, after daily settlement, the client’s margin falls below the exchange’s required margin level, the company shall notify the client to add margin as agreed; if the client fails, the company shall forcibly close some or all positions until the margin can maintain remaining positions.  If close-out instructions cannot be executed due to market reasons after being submitted to the exchange, the company bears no liability.  Fees and losses arising from forced liquidation shall be borne by the client.**Article 74**  Transfers of client margin must meet one of the following:  (1) Payment of margin balance per the client’s instructions;  (2) Deposit of margin or settlement differences to the exchange for the client;  (3) Brokerage commissions, taxes, and other fees payable by the client to the company;  (4) Other situations approved by the CSRC.**Article 75**  Client orders shall specify product, contract month, quantity, buy or sell, open or close, and price.  A company shall not accept discretionary mandates, nor unclear or incomplete orders.  “Discretionary mandate” means the company or its staff decides any of the order elements listed in paragraph 1 on behalf of the client.**Article 76**  Clients may place orders in writing, by telephone, or by other CSRC-approved means.  For telephone orders, the company must record the call; for telex, fax, computer, or other means, the company shall retain records sufficient to prove order contents.**Article 77**  For written orders, a written order ticket shall be filled out, stating:  (1) Client code;  (2) Method of order placement;  (3) Date and time;  (4) Order contents;  (5) Signatures of the salesperson and order placer;  (6) Other necessary items.**Article 78**  Companies shall execute client orders following the principle of time priority.**Article 79**  After market close, the company shall deliver trade confirmations to clients at the time and in the manner agreed.  Confirmations shall state:  (1) Account number and name;  (2) Trade date;  (3) Product and contract month;  (4) Quantity and price;  (5) Buy or sell;  (6) Open or close;  (7) Settlement price of the day;  (8) Margin used and margin balance;  (9) Commissions and other fees;  (10) Taxes;  (11) Other necessary items.**Article 80**  If the client disputes a confirmation, a written objection shall be submitted before the next trading day opens; if no objection, the client shall sign the confirmation or confirm as agreed. Failure to confirm or object shall be deemed confirmation.  For objections, the company shall verify against original order records and trade records.**Article 81**  If results do not conform to the client’s order, or forced liquidation does not meet legal or agreed conditions due to the company’s fault, the company shall, before the next close, re-execute the order or restore the liquidated position and compensate direct losses.  If the client fails to object within the period in Article 80, no further objection may be raised.**Article 82**  The company shall send monthly statements for the preceding month at the agreed time and in the agreed manner, stating:  (1) Account number and name;  (2) Open positions by product at month-end;  (3) Margin deposits/withdrawals and balance for the month;  (4) Trading profits and losses;  (5) Commissions, taxes, and other fees;  (6) Physical deliveries during the month;  (7) Other necessary items.**Article 83**  Where the company sends forced-liquidation notices, margin call notices, trade confirmations, and monthly statements as agreed, the notice obligations under Articles 73, 79, and 82 are deemed fulfilled.**Article 84**  Account-opening data, order records, confirmations, monthly statements, and other business records shall be retained for at least two years; if disputes arise, they shall be kept until the dispute is resolved.**Article 85**  Commissions charged comprise fees collected on behalf of the exchange and the company’s own commissions.  The company’s commission standard shall not be lower than three times the commission standard specified in the futures contract, unless otherwise provided by the CSRC.  Disguised reduction of commission standards is prohibited.---## Chapter IV  Supervision and Administration### Section 1  Financial Administration**Article 86**  In addition to statutory reserves under the *Company Law*, a company shall also appropriate 5% of profits to a surplus reserve.**Article 87**  Companies shall appropriate risk reserves at ratios stipulated by the state and keep them in separate accounts; except as permitted by state rules, reserves shall not be used for other purposes.**Article 88**  Where net assets fall below 60% of registered capital, the company shall, apart from handling existing trades, cease accepting new opening orders, explain the causes to the CSRC local office within three business days, and propose a remediation plan.**Article 89**  Where adjusted net assets to client margin fall below 8%, the company shall report to the CSRC local office within three business days.  If the ratio falls below 4%, the company shall, apart from handling existing trades, cease accepting new opening orders, explain the situation within three business days, and propose a remediation plan.  Adjusted net assets are calculated as:  Adjusted Net Assets = Owners’ Equity + Risk Reserves − Receivables aged over one year − Deferred expenses − Net fixed assets − Intangible assets − Establishment expenses and long-term deferred expenses.**Article 90**  Financial/accounting and settlement functions must be separated into different departments, and a risk assessment system shall be established and improved per CSRC requirements.**Article 91**  The CSRC may adjust the financial ratios in Articles 86, 88, and 89 generally or individually based on company operations and market conditions.### Section 2  License Administration**Article 92**  *Futures Brokerage Business Licenses* and *Business Department Operating Licenses* are uniformly designed and printed by the CSRC.  Forgery, alteration, leasing, lending, transfer, or sale of licenses is prohibited.**Article 93**  If a license (original or copy) is lost or seriously damaged, the company shall, within 30 days of discovery, announce its invalidation in CSRC-recognized newspapers and apply to the CSRC for reissuance with the announcement attached.**Article 94**  The contents on the business license of the company or business department must be consistent with those on the relevant CSRC license.### Section 3  Routine Supervision and Inspection**Article 95**  Companies shall establish and strictly implement risk management and internal control systems.**Article 96**  Companies shall appoint internal auditors to periodically or randomly audit finance and business operations and compliance with laws, regulations, policies, articles, and business rules, and prepare audit reports for record.**Article 97**  The CSRC and its local offices may conduct routine inspections at any time.  The main items include:  (1) Whether approval procedures for establishment or changes are complete;  (2) Consistency between application materials and actual conditions;  (3) Authenticity and adequacy of capital or working capital;  (4) Whether business is within the approved scope;  (5) Whether there are illegal operations;  (6) Whether business operations are sound;  (7) Whether premises and trading facilities meet requirements;  (8) Whether required reports are submitted;  (9) Other matters deemed necessary.**Article 98**  Local offices shall conduct ad hoc inspections on:  (1) Implementation of the margin system by companies and business departments;  (2) Implementation of risk management and internal control systems;  (3) Other ad hoc items deemed necessary.  Companies lacking such systems shall be ordered to rectify and be subject to focused inspection.**Article 99**  Companies and business departments shall submit monthly operating and financial reports to their local CSRC office in the required format.**Article 100**  Within 10 days of occurrence, companies shall report to the local CSRC office any of:  (1) Replacement of directors or supervisors;  (2) Equity investments of RMB 1 million or more;  (3) Pending litigation of RMB 500,000 or more;  (4) Opening or resumption of business;  (5) Other matters prescribed by the CSRC.**Article 101**  A company may apply to the CSRC to suspend operations of the company or a business department, with a plan for handling clients’ positions and margins; suspension shall take effect upon CSRC approval.  Upon approval, licenses shall be returned to the CSRC.### Section 4  Annual Inspection**Article 102**  The CSRC shall conduct annual inspections (“annual review”) of companies to confirm business qualifications.  The format of the annual report, inspection label, and stamp shall be unified by the CSRC.**Article 103**  New companies shall participate in the following year’s inspection.  Companies penalized with suspension shall participate after rectification and acceptance by the CSRC.  Suspended companies or business departments shall participate after resumption.**Article 104**  Annual inspection covers:  (1) Changes to the business license;  (2) Financial conditions;  (3) Compliance with laws, regulations, rules, and policies;  (4) Formulation and implementation of internal rules;  (5) Handling of client complaints;  (6) Other matters prescribed by the CSRC.**Article 105**  Within 15 days of receiving notice, companies shall submit:  (1) Annual inspection report;  (2) Audited financial statements by a qualified accounting firm;  (3) Copy of the business license (copy);  (4) Other materials required by the CSRC.**Article 106**  Local offices conduct preliminary reviews and submit materials and opinions to the CSRC for re-examination.  If qualified, the CSRC will affix the inspection label or stamp to the license.**Article 107**  For companies not conforming to applicable requirements, the CSRC shall order suspension for rectification or revoke the license.### Section 5  Special Procedures for Margin-Refund Crises**Article 108**  Where a company has experienced or may experience a client margin refund crisis that seriously affects client interests, the CSRC may decide to implement special handling.**Article 109**  A special handling decision shall state:  (1) The company name;  (2) Reasons;  (3) Duration.**Article 110**  Upon entry into special handling, the company’s shareholders shall organize a special handling working group. If necessary, the CSRC local office may send representatives or engage intermediaries to participate.  The working group’s work is subject to CSRC supervision.**Article 111**  From the commencement of special handling, operating and management authority shall be exercised by the working group.  Debts and claims arising during the period shall continue to be borne by the company.**Article 112**  The working group may take measures including:  (1) Verifying clients’ positions, margin balances, and causes of the crisis;  (2) Disposing of company assets and recovering due claims;  (3) Recovering misappropriated client margins;  (4) Deciding plans for handling clients’ positions and margins;  (5) Formulating and implementing a rectification plan;  (6) Other necessary measures.**Article 113**  If liquidation is deemed necessary during special handling, the working group may apply to the CSRC; liquidation may proceed upon approval.**Article 114**  Upon expiry, the CSRC may extend special handling, but the total duration shall not exceed one year.**Article 115**  Special handling shall terminate upon any of:  (1) Expiry of the specified or extended period;  (2) Restoration of normal operating capability before expiry;  (3) Merger or bankruptcy of the company before expiry.---## Chapter V  Penalties**Article 116**  Where a company commits any of the following, penalties shall be imposed pursuant to Article 59 of the *Interim Regulations on the Administration of Futures Trading*:  (1) Failure to perform reporting or filing obligations;  (2) Opening accounts for ineligible entities or individuals in violation of Article 52;  (3) Failure to examine client eligibility and credit per Article 53;  (4) Failure to meet CSRC financial requirements after a rectification deadline;  (5) Providing guarantees in violation of regulations or becoming an investor bearing unlimited liability;  (6) False statements or major omissions in application materials;  (7) Establishing business departments via joint venture or cooperation;  (8) Contracting out or leasing business departments;  (9) Opening additional premises for a business department;  (10) Disguised reduction of commission or margin standards;  (11) Failure to establish complaint files and error-order records;  (12) Speculating in stocks in violation of regulations.**Article 117**  Where a company commits any of the following, penalties shall be imposed pursuant to Article 60 of the *Interim Regulations on the Administration of Futures Trading*:  (1) Improper handling of a business department’s clients’ positions and margins, or unauthorized transfer of its assets;  (2) Accepting client orders outside lawfully established business premises;  (3) Accepting orders from clients who have not completed account-opening procedures;  (4) Inducing clients to trade through false publicity;  (5) Misrepresenting the company’s credit standing, or citing the CSRC’s business license as a guarantee of capability or financial soundness;  (6) Evading debts by withdrawing capital or concealing assets.**Article 118**  Other violations of these Measures shall be punished pursuant to the *Interim Regulations on the Administration of Futures Trading*.**Article 119**  Those who violate these Measures and cause damage to others shall bear civil liability according to law.---## Chapter VI  Supplementary Provisions**Article 120**  Futures brokerage companies lawfully established before the implementation of these Measures may continue to exist; those not fully meeting the conditions herein shall meet them within the timeframe prescribed by the CSRC.**Article 121**  Where provisions issued before the implementation of these Measures are inconsistent with these Measures, these Measures shall prevail.**Article 122**  These Measures shall be interpreted by the CSRC.**Article 123**  These Measures shall come into force on September 1, 1999.  ① Repealed by the *Measures for the Administration of Futures Brokerage Companies* (CSRC Order No. 7, May 17, 2002).  ② Repealed by the *Notice of the CSRC on Repealing Certain Securities and Futures Rules (Batch IV)* (CSRC Legal Affairs [2003] No. 15, November 20, 2003).
